Currently, if someone calls 988 from the State of New Hampshire, their 603 phone number, their call will be routed to local crisis centers in New Hampshire, even if they find themselves far from the Granite State and in need of local assistance. Commissioner Starks, can you speak to how the FCC is working to address this issue and what more needs to be done?
Mr. Starks. Yes. Thank you so much for the question. Thank you for your leadership and hard work on this critical issue. It has been just about 2 years now that 988 has been up and running, and we...

messages.content: Lead a discussion on the effectiveness and future improvements of the 988 crisis line.

It has been just about 2 years now that 988 has been up and running, and we continue to build on that tremendous success. Nearly 10 million calls that we have had. We continue to make sure that folks that are dealing with this life crisis have a place that they can call.

And so, to your point, making sure that they can interact with a local counselor is something that we have heard from mental health advocates, and that is where we are pushing for our policymaking to go.
It has been such a cooperative effort between industry, mental health, HHS, SAMHSA. Everybody here has been working so hard together for the American people that are in crisis this way.
Do you think there is some kind of option where they could say where their location is and it wouldn't just be driven by the area code?
It would not be driven by the area code. It would be based upon where the cell phone is pinging off of.
Okay. Great. That is very helpful. Thank you so much, and we look forward to working with you.
Discuss the FCC's spectrum auction authority and its implications.

As Congress works to restore the FCC's spectrum auction authority, can you explain what role the FCC plays in setting technical rules for particular spectrum bands, and are there specific factors that Congress should keep in mind?
I think our record on this is extraordinary. We are the first...
particular spectrum bands, and are there specific factors that Congress should keep in mind?

Ms. Rosenworcel. I think our record on this is extraordinary. We are the first country in the world to auction off airwaves. We are the first country in the world to hold incentive auctions. We are the first country in the world to have creative dynamic sharing systems to allow for hierarchies of spectrum rights. We are the first country in the world to take garbage unused spectrum and turn it into unlicensed airwaves which are used for WiFi. In other words, the record of the United States and the FCC to take airwaves and put them to market is second to none. The challenge we face going forward is there are more things we are connecting wirelessly -- more people, more places, more things -- and the reality is we are going to need more spectrum to continue to fuel that. So what we will need from Congress is renewing that spectrum authority, and we will need some details on which bands you think we should approach next and convert perhaps from Federal use to new commercial use. Ms. Kuster. Great. Very helpful. Thank you. I will just close by saying, broadband is an essential service in today's digital world, and I appreciate all of the work that you all are doing to make it more accessible and affordable for our constituents. Thank you so much. This is an unedited transcript. The statements within may be inaccurate, incomplete, or misattributed to the speaker.
Mr. Latta. Thank you. The gentlelady yields back. And the chair now recognizes the gentlelady from Tennessee's First District for 5 minutes for questions.
Mrs. Harshbarger. Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Thank you witnesses for being here today.

content: The following conversation takes place in a congressional hearing setting.
And the chair now recognizes the gentlelady from Tennessee's First District for 5 minutes for questions.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Thank you witnesses for being here today. You know, the First District of Tennessee is home to a large amount of Federal land, specifically the Great Smoky Mountains National Park and the Cherokee National Forest. Updating wireless internet infrastructure on Federal lands is currently bogged down in the red tape of NEPA and the National Historic Preservation Act. I can tell you firsthand, some of the most difficult places in my district to get quality service is going to be the Great Smoky Mountains and the Cherokee National Forest. And that is just hurting our communities. In February, I introduced the Wireless Broadband Competition and Efficient Deployment Act, which would roll back the red tape, keeping these communities on Federal lands from getting the infrastructure to stay connected. My question is for you, Commissioner Carr. How important is it for Congress to take an active role in turning down these barriers to broadband deployment like overburdensome and sometimes ridiculous permitting requirements?

Thanks, Congresswoman, for your leadership, particularly on Federal lands, where it simply takes too long and costs too much to build out. I was just on another national park myself last week, Shenandoah. And I had virtually no cell phone service. In fact, I had to climb this small little tower to get any service at all. I ended up climbing that mountain a lot, fairly addicted to the internet. And so I think we need to move forward with legislation and leadership that you are showing and generally taking a look at permitting reform. Look, we have been spending a lot of money, $800 billion, again by my count; $42 billion of that for broadband specifically. We need to make sure it’s being used effectively.
You are a helpful assistant.
Programs are making accessible connected devices that are verified and can be trusted?

Mr. Carr. One thing that we can do is complete our proceeding that is looking at these TCBs in labs. I think another step that I have called for is for the FCC to look at the entities we do regulate and prohibit them from interconnecting with insecure entities, including China Mobile and China Telecom, to the extent that they are not even offering necessarily Title I or Title II services. I think that is one thing that the FCC should be doing.

In the past year, the FCC has adopted rules governing broadband labels, digital discrimination, net neutrality, and data breaches. And you are considering more rules in these areas and in other areas, like outage reporting. So my question is, can a company with 20, 30, 50 employees really keep up with all of this without significant burdens to that company? We want them to survive, but how can they do that?

Mr. Carr. I think what people lose sight of is that the broadband builders in this country that are truly bridging the digital divide in rural communities, it is not these large corporate behemoths. In many cases, it is mom-and-pop operations, small 20-person operations, and they are confronting a regulatory onslaught from Washington. We need to sort of decrease that regulation and that will help unleash their ability to build. Look, they are already dealing with inflation, they are already dealing with high fuel prices. And on top of that we are raising the regulatory cost. Again, BEAD I think is a perfect example where the Biden administration is layering on all of these regulatory costs that Congress specifically either prohibited them from doing or didn’t authorize.
You are participating in a discussion about regulatory policies and their impacts on internet accessibility programs, particularly the ACP initiative in the United States.

The administration is holding up applications from Tennessee and other States. They are compelling Tennessee to engage in price controls and rate regulation to get the money owed through BEAD, which seems to be slowing things down and is viewed as bad policy. What are your thoughts on decreasing these regulations?

Decreasing permitting and general regulations could potentially streamline the process and avoid unnecessary delays. However, it's important to balance this with ensuring fair pricing and access for all consumers.

Thank you. I wanted to highlight how the Affordable Connectivity Program (ACP) has lowered internet bills for 23 million American families. This is particularly important in my district in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, which is largely lower income. How does this reflect on rural areas and the expiration of ACP?

The ACP has indeed been beneficial nationwide, especially in rural areas where access to affordable internet is critical. However, the potential expiration of the ACP poses a significant risk to those 23 million families who rely on it, and solutions need to be sought to prevent disruption in affordable internet access.

messages.content: I have a question for Chairwoman Rosenworcel. Has the FCC heard directly from impacted consumers that are having to navigate this new post-ACP world? I was wondering if you could kind of weigh in on that. And Commissioner Starks and Gomez are also welcome to join in. Thank you.

Ms. Rosenworcel: Yeah, we have heard from lots and lots of consumers. We have seen a 40 percent increase in the number of complaints about billing and charges related to ACP. These are people who are angry, upset, and bewildered by the fact this program has come to an end. They are from rural America, urban America, and everything in between. A disproportionate number of them are elderly, single parents, and retired military. And we have got heartbreaking emails that come to my inbox every day.

And I know that Commissioner Starks and Commissioner Gomez spoke eloquently about this in their statements, so I would love it if they would continue the discussion. Mr. Starks: Yes, thank you. Agree with all that. You know, the numbers simply show that one in six households in America are enrolled. That is a big number. That is impacting a lot of folks.
You are a helpful assistant.

One thing that I would like to highlight for you, Congressman. One of the initiatives that I had was Your Home, Your Internet, making sure that those that were in Federal housing assistance, HUD housing, Section 8 housing, that they knew about the program, they automatically were qualified. When I started that initiative, about 500,000 eligible households were enrolled. After the momentum that the FCC gained on it, nearly 2 million at the time of the freeze were enrolled. So it is a real number of folks that started to know about the program, see what it could benefit for them for telehealth, telemedicine, for young learners. And so I wanted to highlight that in the work that we have done coordinating with HUD, which is extraordinarily important.

Thank you, Congressman. And by the way, thank you for the call as well. I enjoyed speaking with you very much. I absolutely agree with everything that the chairwoman and Commissioner Starks have said. We are hearing from consumers, heartbreaking emails that we get from them just about every day. In addition, when we go visit localities, we hear from parents who are extremely worried about how they are going to afford connectivity for their children. We hear from seniors who are relying on the ACP in order to maintain connections. And we hear from the veterans. This is both urban and rural areas nationwide, so it is a significant problem. As I mentioned earlier, I have lived with not having the resources to pay my bills and having to make the difficult decision between paying for food or paying for a phone bill. And this was before connectivity became so crucial to our daily lives. So this is a significant issue, and thank you for your leadership.

Mr. Veasey, if Congress is able to fund the ACP before the end of July, can the program be restarted using possible bridge funding of $7 billion to $8 billion? And do you think it also makes sense to include ACP in an update to the USF?

Ms. Gomez: Thank you for that question. First of all, I very much encourage the efforts on updating the USF. We want to make sure that it is sustainable. And putting ACP as part of the USF funding would make it sustainable as well and then we wouldn't have to have these conversations every few months.
Ms. Gomez, would bridge funding be helpful for restarting the program if passed by the end of July?
Ms. Gomez: To answer your question, bridge funding would certainly be helpful. And if Congress passed it by the end of July, I would probably come here and do cartwheels.
Mrs. Miller-Meeks, thank you for holding this hearing. What concerns have you heard from constituents regarding spending priorities?

Mrs. Miller-Meeks: I am hearing some very harsh language from the other side of the aisle; perhaps if we prioritized our spending we wouldn't be worried about whether or not we get the money. But all I know is rampant $1.9 trillion COVID spending at the beginning of this Biden-Harris administration led to rampant inflation.

Can you explain how the Biden-Harris administration's decision to add additional red tape is causing unnecessary delays and jeopardizing the BEAD broadband deployment program? Particularly given that $42 billion has been allocated but progress seems stagnant.

Thank you for the question. I will start with your point about ACP and spending. The FCC conducted its own survey and found that out of this $17 billion, only 15 percent of respondents said they would lose internet service if the program expired. I believe as Congress looks into ACP, the focus should be on the 15 percent, or whatever number truly requires it, instead of pouring more money into the existing setup. 

As for the BEAD initiative, despite the $42 billion promise to connect millions of Americans, 967 days have passed without any tangible progress, such as construction projects commencing. This delay is attributed to the additional red tape which has stalled progress rather than facilitating swift action to connect the nation.
This is an unedited transcript. The statements within may be inaccurate, incomplete, or misattributed to the speaker.

Do you think the program will be a success, more importantly? And then, how do we define success? To me, it should be defined by the number of households, the number of businesses that have been connected.

I think BEAD is a program that is worth fighting for, but it needs a course correction. We can still do it. Let's stop trying to pursue DEI and just bridge the digital divide. Let's stop pushing these climate change agendas and just connect communities. If we can do those things and get rid of the extraneous political improvising, I think this program will get closer to getting back on track.

content: This is an unedited transcript. The statements within may be inaccurate, incomplete, or misattributed to the speaker.

Mr. Simington. Absolutely. So the Universal Service Fund, of course, dates back to the Telecommunications Act of 1996, at a time when the landline market was a lot bigger than it is now. Thus, on the front end of contributions, it is very difficult to fund a growing program out of a shrinking base.

Now, if you look at what the landline network was supposed to do, universal service says it was supposed to connect all Americans in a single network. In fact, it was to be a network that was intercompatible with all the networks worldwide and, thus, it benefited from the network effects of scale. Today, the beneficiaries of the networks effects of scale are online companies primarily. So to put it another way, when Comcast gains a customer, it is not just Comcast; it is Google, it is Meta, it is Amazon. These are the companies that benefit even more from universal connectivity than individual network operators who do not have the same advantages of scale.
Mrs. Miller-Meeks. How would you change that?
Mr. Simington. Well, I think by contribution reform, we would say that the main beneficiaries of these network effects should be considered as contributors.

Mrs. Miller-Meeks. Thank you. And lastly, more of a comment, because I think this question has been asked and answered, but in agricultural heavy states like Iowa, the advancement of precision agriculture is essential for our farmers to remain competitive and efficient. Widespread and ubiquitous either broadband or wireless coverage. And I have been in the combine with farmers who are using -- or use Starlink. I have visited with our manufacturers as well.

input.content: It is really important for the adoption and importation of precision agriculture technologies, which would meet some of those sustainability goals that you are trying to implement. And I would just encourage the FCC to expand and enhance wireless availability, as was mentioned earlier, to meet the growing demands, but also to ensure that the BEAD program is put in place and enacted, and let the providers get to do the work that they do because they are extraordinarily frustrated in my State. And then, a question for the record. Chairman Rosenworcel, answer a question for the record, we would just like to ask what the FCC's role is in spectrum studies that NTIA is leading.

Thank you for your input and question. The FCC plays a crucial role in spectrum studies by collaborating with the NTIA to manage and allocate spectrum resources effectively. The aim is to ensure that there is enough bandwidth available for emerging technologies, including precision agriculture, which relies heavily on robust and widespread wireless connectivity. We are committed to working towards enhancing wireless availability to meet growing demands and encourage innovation.

We live in a time of incredible technological advances: autonomous vehicles, artificial intelligence, e-commerce, telehealth, online education. All these things are going through our committee as we speak, and all require high-speed internet; connections that we need to make sure every American has to flourish. On the $42 billion fund for high-speed internet, as well as the $14.2 billion Affordable Connectivity Program, both are part of making this access available to everyone, especially in rural areas. I have both urban, suburban, and rural in our district. And the FCC, you all stand at the vanguard of this progress. The only complaints I hear back home from local folks is it is not happening fast enough and that the Affordable Connectivity Program ran out.

Thank you for highlighting these concerns. The $42 billion fund for high-speed internet and the $14.2 billion Affordable Connectivity Program are significant steps towards ensuring that every American, regardless of their location, has access to the internet. We acknowledge the feedback that the rollout could be faster and the concerns about the Affordable Connectivity Program running out of funds. The FCC is continuously working to expedite these processes and exploring ways to extend the program's reach and sustainability.

content: Commissioner Gomez, thank you so much for coming to the district, to the Orlando VA, and speaking with local veterans, including many disabled, wounded warriors. And as you mentioned, 80 percent of medical treatments our veterans are undertaking require broadband connection. And ACP has provided benefits to 79,000 households in my district and has reduced cost by $37 million. And so can you expand on the importance you think the ACP program plays, especially in healthcare and for our veterans?

Thank you, Congressman, for that question. And thank you again for the visit in Orlando at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center. It was really interesting, and I really appreciated hearing directly from beneficiaries of the Affordable Connectivity Program. As you mentioned, 80 percent of healthcare from that medical center requires a connection to broadband. And we heard from so many folks during that visit about the importance of connectivity and the ways that it actually saves costs for these very veterans, particularly veterans with disabilities. If they need to go to a hearing in order for their benefits, before they had broadband connectivity, they would have to get in the car or a van, drive for hours, get a hotel room for at least a couple of days, in order just to be able to attend the hearing. Now they can do it online, and that saves them costs, it saves the government costs. So that is just one example of the things that we heard when we were visiting with the VA center.

Thank you. Commissioner Starks, as you may know, I filed the Launch Communications Act again. It has passed the House again. We appreciate the Commission's important work on the issue of ensuring greater spectrum for launches.

messages.content: You are a helpful assistant.

Can you please discuss the need to expand the amount of spectrum that is available for commercial space launches and reentries and the importance of streamlining the process for accessing spectrum for this use?

Yes. It has been extremely important. We are seeing more launches than ever. We need to keep pace with the technology, keep pace with innovation. And we have been able to with the Space Bureau here, now be able to move quicker, be able to be more nimble. And it has been more important than ever as we are getting more and more connectivity and more of what satellite is going to look like.
You are a helpful assistant.
What can the Congress do to make sure the United States continues to lead in building a competitive and dynamic space marketplace?

Well, thank you. I know that Kennedy Space Center and Cape Canaveral are in your backyard. And I had the privilege of going there last year and meeting with the Artemis 2 astronauts. And it really is an out of this world experience what is happening. We have had, nationally, more than 200 space launches in the last year. It is no small feat to continue leading in such a rapidly growing industry. Supporting policies that encourage innovation and competition, investing in infrastructure, and ensuring effective collaboration between public and private sectors can help maintain the United States' leadership in the space marketplace.
Mr. Fulcher, Thank you for recognizing the importance of speeding up the approval processes across Federal lands involving NEPA and the National Historic Preservation Act.

Indeed, fast-tracking these processes is vital for bolstering our nation's space capabilities and commercial space industry. The concept of a Federal Lands Desk was mentioned as a potential solution to streamline these approvals. Have there been any developments on this front since our last discussion?

content: You are a helpful assistant.
Is there anything further on the Federal Lands Desk, or is this something that we need to take further steps for here?

I think we need to continue to move forward. There are a lot of infrastructure ideas that we can do. For instance, we've streamlined many rules at the FCC that apply to small cells, just one type of technology. We need to extend those to more technologies. The Federal Lands Desk could help as Congress has tried to streamline the permitting process for Federal lands. Agencies often have other important work and don't process these quickly enough. If we had an FCC place to help with these applications, it might be beneficial.
I've heard about backlogs being a concern within BLM for service. Are you hearing anything like that?

We hear about this constantly. I've visited places across the West where you see laydown yards with multiple antennas and miles of conduit just sitting there. The hard part, like getting all that equipment out there and purchasing it, is done. They're just waiting on government approvals to build it. That's a significant problem.

messages.content: You are a participant in a congressional hearing discussing the challenges of building infrastructure on federal lands and regulatory issues affecting communication providers.
Commissioner Rosenworcel, could you comment on the delays in approvals for building on federal lands?

Yes, that's a significant point. About one-third of our land nationwide is federally owned, and these areas are the least built out in terms of communications infrastructure. The Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act required the GSA to create a standard form, Form 299, for federal agencies when approached for construction projects. However, responses can take up to 270 days, whereas state and local deadlines are 90 to 150 days. We need quicker response times from federal authorities, and I recommend looking into the status of Form 299.
Thank you for that. Commissioner Carr, could you discuss the Title II proposal's impact on small and rural providers, especially around potential price controls?

Certainly. The Title II proposal raises concerns about possible price controls within the industry, which particularly affects small and rural providers in states like yours. It's crucial to consider these impacts and address any issues that may hinder their operations.

content: I am concerned about the impact of potential price controls on rural providers in my State. Is this a real concern and what should we be doing about it?

Price controls, as a policy matter, are the wrong direction. We need to attract billions of dollars into these networks. There is a risk with the FCC's Digital Equity Order opening the door to rate regulations, even though it disavows this in the separate Title II decision. Some States are already trying to impose price controls, and the Commerce Department is pressuring others to adopt them, despite the law you passed against it. It's a legal and policy mistake.
You are a helpful assistant.
Mr. Latta. Thank you. The time of the gentleman has expired. The chair now recognizes the gentlelady from the Seventh District in Texas for 5 minutes of questions.

Mrs. Fletcher. Thank you so much, Chairman Latta, and thank you, Ranking Member Matsui, for convening today's hearing. And thank you to our commissioners for being here to testify about the FCC and the many important issues under its jurisdiction.

And as many of you, I think probably everyone here has seen, Hurricane Beryl hit the Texas Gulf Coast yesterday with my hometown of Houston right in the path of the storm, when this Category 1 hurricane made landfall yesterday and made it right through Houston and our area.

Mrs. Fletcher. As of last night, there were 2.2 million people without power, including at my own home. And I know that our folks on the ground are working as hard and as quickly as possible to restore power and to restore communications.

And I have spoken with a lot of our local communications providers who have established backup power sources to make sure that my constituents don't lose their ability to be in contact with emergency responders, with family, with friends, and to try to make sure that they can get through the storm during this emergency.

Mrs. Fletcher. So, Chairwoman Rosenworcel, I really want to thank you and thank all of your colleagues for the Mandatory Disaster Response Initiative, MDRI. For those who don't know, these are new rules that took effect in May that require wireless providers to take certain actions to improve and reduce the impact of wireless outages and support faster service restoration during emergencies like this one. It has been absolutely critical that people have been able to be in contact.

messages.content: You are a helpful assistant in a conversation.

And, you know, one of the actions, of course, is requiring backup power sources for cell sites and infrastructure, and that has proved to be very important, as I really haven't had trouble reaching people, other than that they maybe can't keep their devices powered. So those are huge challenges. And I know that in response to Beryl, the FCC announced the activation of the Disaster Information Reporting System and for the first time this mandatory initiative. So, Chairwoman Rosenworcel, with the time that we have, can you just talk a little bit about why it was important for the FCC to move this from a voluntary program to a mandatory program? And maybe just explain a little bit about what that will mean for my constituents, what some of the actions are that are required, and how in moments like this where we are really in crisis how your agency is working to help make sure that we have the resources and information that we need to stay in communication.

Yeah. Thank you.
Everyone needs communication, and especially in crisis. And, unfortunately, the Texas Gulf Coast has had more than its fair share of weather events, and as a result, we started the disaster system that takes in data about when services are down. We also sent individuals down to the Houston area to work with FEMA on this. We have a lot of people who do that work, they do it quietly. They are real heroes. They go and get some ground troops throughout the state of communications and help with restoration. And we also have a first test case of our Mandatory Disaster Response Initiative.
You are a helpful assistant.

And we also have a first test case of our Mandatory Disaster Response Initiative which requires carriers to work with one another and let their customers roam on each other's networks. This was previously a volunteer initiative, but I went with Commissioner Carr after Hurricane Ida to Louisiana. We spoke with a lot of public safety officials, and they convinced us both that this should be required.

Thank you for sharing this update. It's great to see actions being taken to improve communication infrastructure, especially during disasters. Is there anything specific about the implementation or challenges you've encountered?
You are a helpful assistant.

So after Hurricane Beryl leaves the Houston area, one thing we are going to do is find out how it worked, because we want to make sure it works for everyone going forward. This is both a tragedy, but I think it is also an opportunity. I think you are going to be able to demonstrate to us how our carriers worked with one another and kept people connected.

Indeed, analyzing how the systems performed during Hurricane Beryl will provide valuable insights for optimizing the response in future incidents. Are there specific metrics or data you will be looking at to evaluate the effectiveness of the initiative?
You are a helpful assistant.

Mrs. Fletcher. Well, thank you so much for that. And I have a little bit more time, so I also want to ask, one of the challenges we are seeing is, of course, keeping track of outages of all kinds, including the power outages. But also, I know that the agency recently issued an order classifying broadband as Title II service that will give the FCC insight into network outages, and that will ultimately, I think, benefit people in my district and across the country. Can you just talk a little bit more about what that will mean?

Ms. Rosenworcel. Yeah. When broadband goes out, a community goes down. When it goes out in my house, you know, my children are ready for revolution. It is one of those circumstances that affects everything in modern life. It is why the Federal Communications Commission needs the authority to collect data about outages, not just in the aftermath of weather disasters, but also outages that occur when we least expect them.

content: You are a helpful assistant for a congressional hearing transcript.
There was a community in Michigan that lost service during the pandemic for 45 days, but the FCC had no data or information about it.

Now that we have Title II authority back, we will be able to collect information about outages, understand why they occur, and then take action to prevent them from occurring again, which is really, really important for all of us who count on the internet in our day-to-day life.
Mrs. Fletcher: Well, thank you so much for that. And I am glad to hear about how the commissioners are working together in this instance.

I don't have time for another question, but with the 10 seconds I have left, I don't think I can close without mentioning my surprise that FCC officials that are nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate are listed as contributors to the Project 2025 plan, which is really a blueprint for dismantling our government and eviscerating agencies like this one and others and fundamentally changing our country. So I am surprised and very disappointed to see that. And with that, I yield back.
Mr. Latta: The gentlelady's time has expired. The chair now recognizes the gentlelady from Florida's Third District for 5 minutes for questioning.
Mrs. Cammack: Well, thank you, Mr. Chairman. Thank you to our commissioners for appearing before us here today.

I will start with you, Chairwoman. In June, the chairman of the Federal Elections Commission sent you a letter regarding the FCC proposed regulations on AI and political advertisements. Now, in the letter, Chairman Cooksey stated that the FCC lacks the legal authority to promulgate conflicting disclaimers requirements only for political communication. He also stated that it would create confusion and disarray among political campaigns.
You are a helpful assistant.

Now, have you spoken to Chair Cooksey about this proposal, and do you plan to move forward following the FEC's concerns about the authority and political speech? I apologize, I am in three conflicting hearings today, so if this has been asked, I appreciate you answering it again.

First of all, I believe in transparency. I believe every single consumer should know if AI is being used. I think it is good for truth, honesty, and safety that every single one of us knows if AI is being used. I spoke to the vice chair of the FEC who thinks that we have complementary authority here, because since 1930, the FCC has been requiring campaigns, when they advertise on television and radio, to file with us what ad they put up, when it ran, and how much they paid for it.
Did you speak with the chair, not the vice chair?
I have only spoken to the vice chair, but the truth is we have a long history.
So the chair and the vice chair have differing opinions on this?
Yeah. They have a difference of opinion. The vice chair says that, clearly, we have complementary authority in this area. I agree with that.

messages.content: You are a helpful assistant.
Mrs. Cammack. So what is the plan, because we are less than 5 months out from a significant election?

Ms. Rosenworcel. I agree with you, but what I have proposed is a rulemaking to collect public comment on whether advertisements that are run on our televisions and radios should disclose if they use AI.
You are a helpful assistant.
Mrs. Cammack. I don't think that requires a whole comment period because by and large, everyone wants transparency, right? Is it a matter of whether the FCC has the authority to do so?

Mr. Carr. The proposal from the FCC to regulate political speech with new disclosures on the eve of a national election is both unlawful and misguided. The FEC has exclusive authority over such disclosures, and this could lead to confusion as the rules wouldn't uniformly apply to all platforms.
So I think the FCC should abandon this proposal because it can only move forward This is an unedited transcript. The statements within may be inaccurate, incomplete, or misattributed to the speaker.

Right on the eve of an election, this is an important debate, the use of AI, no doubt. However, that debate should be happening here in Congress, and it is happening at the FEC as well. It is just not a job for the FCC right now.
Ms. Rosenworcel, what are your thoughts on the current initiative?
I don't know why we are so scared of --
Mrs. Cammack. I am sorry, I have to -- I have to reclaim my time.
The gentlelady from Florida is asking the questions and has the floor.
Mrs. Cammack, would you like to change the topic?
Chairwoman, I have got to jump to another issue. Thank you, Commissioner Carr, for that feedback.
Ms. Rosenworcel, any issue with that?
No problem.
What is the status of the 4.9 gigahertz band decision?
The 4.9 gigahertz band is very important for first responders' public safety. Right now, we are taking in comments from all kinds of public safety authorities.
Could you clarify the options available regarding this band?
To be clear, it is not a question of whether it will go to FirstNet or be auctioned. It depends on what public safety authorities might be managing these airwaves going forward.
Do we have a timeline for this decision?

My hope is that we can do this within the next several months. However, a lot of people are filing a lot of stuff before us, and when it comes at us fast and furious, we have to spend some time looking at it and reading it carefully.

content: This is a conversation during a congressional hearing focusing on AI and broadband access.

Mrs. Cammack. There is a lot more that I wish I could get to. I wish you guys could see my notes here, or maybe not, I am not sure. But I want to leave us in the last 22 seconds with this. I agree with you, Commissioner Carr, that this could severely muddy the waters when we are talking about AI.

While I agree wholeheartedly that we need transparency and clarity about the use of AI in political advertisements, the FEC has jurisdiction over this issue. And the fact that there are divided opinions, conflicting opinions within the FCC, and that you have not spoken to the chair of the FEC, is concerning. So with that, my time has expired. And, Mr. Chairman, I yield.
Mr. Latta. Thank you. The gentlelady's time has expired. And the chair now recognizes the gentleman from New York, who is waiving on to the subcommittee, who is a member of the full committee.

Mr. Tonko. Thank you, Chair Latta and Ranking Member Matsui, for holding this hearing, and the chair and commissioners for your service in being here today. Before I go on with my questioning, Chair Rosenworcel, I think you wanted to make a statement in response to the AI issue yet.
Ms. Rosenworcel. I just think transparency is a good thing, disclosing when AI use is a good thing. And the FCC has authority in this area and has had authority since the 1930s.

Mr. Tonko. Thank you. Throughout my tenure in Congress, I have championed efforts to extend broadband access to unserved and underserved areas. Last Congress, I was proud to support the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, which allocated over $42 billion for high-speed broadband deployment nationwide. With these historic investments, accurate broadband maps are essential for the equitable and effective allocation of Federal funds.

Chairman Rosenworcel, I appreciated your work on behalf of my district, visiting the district and listening carefully to what my constituents had to say about this issue. And I appreciate your written testimony on the National Broadband Map, and commend the FCC for the substantial progress made in updating these maps over the past few years. However, in the Capital Region of New York, we are still seeing the effects of unreliable data. Communities often struggle with slow speeds, unreliable connections, or no service, despite being designated as having access. This disparity can hamper economic development and perpetuate systemic inequalities, widening the digital divide. So can you speak please, Commissioner Chair, to how the FCC is incorporating consumer-reported data on broadband availability and quality into its mapping efforts and the role public feedback plays in efforts to refine our broadband maps?

Ms. Rosenworcel. Yeah. Public feedback is so important. We built maps based on the Broadband DATA Act, which is bipartisan work of this committee. Those maps are light years ahead of anything we have ever had before, and they are iterative. They are improving all the time. The primary way that they improve is when consumers and State and local governments provide their data and feedback.

messages.content: Can you discuss how the FCC collaborates with other Federal agencies, State governments, and industry stakeholders to streamline broadband mapping efforts and ensure a cohesive approach to improving nationwide broadband access?

Yeah, it is a really, really big task, to be candid with you. When I got to the agency and I took over, one of the first things I did was say, okay, we are going to do better maps. And then I studied it and I instantly understood why nobody had done it before. We had to build a data set of tax records, property records, satellite images that indicated where every single household is in the United States. And then we had to build a system that was capable of taking in data from all of our carriers, and then feedback and crowdsourced information from local, State, Tribal, and consumers all telling us what is going on. The system right now is terrific. We have got 115 million households that we indicate where broadband is. We know that in 6 million of them it is not present. But it can always be improved. That is why we update it every 6 months.

content: You are a helpful assistant.

Could you discuss any initiatives the FCC is undertaking to raise public awareness about the availability and purpose of 988, especially among vulnerable populations that may benefit most from the service?

Certainly. We are seeing substantial increases in the use of 988, the simple three-digit number. More people understand it, and more people know about it. We are getting many more calls than we previously did under the 10-digit number that was hard for folks to remember. We are working on publicizing it further with mental health authorities to ensure that it reaches vulnerable populations effectively. This involves targeted outreach and collaboration with various stakeholders to raise awareness about the service and its availability, especially focusing on groups that are most in need.

messages.content: Chair Rosenworcel, it is very nice to see you again. I would like to continue a line of questioning that was started by my colleague from Florida, Mrs. Cammack, about the FCC's recent actions to put restrictions on the use of AI in political advertising. And to be clear, I don’t think anyone disagrees with the importance of putting some guidelines in place. I think everyone is disturbed by the thought that a campaign could run an ad with their opponent saying or doing something that they didn’t actually do with the use of AI to make that happen. But we want to make sure that we get this done in the appropriate way. And Mrs. Cammack highlighted the fact that the chair of the FEC has objected to the FCC's use of your regulatory authority to do this, and so I just wanted to ask a couple questions about that.
You are a helpful assistant.

Mr. Obernolte, I'm concerned about desensitization caused by inconsistent ad disclosures across different channels. People may assume all channels show disclosures, leading to potential misunderstanding.

I understand your concern. That's why it's crucial to handle this properly. The AI Task Force has examined this issue, emphasizing that it's more complex than just mandating a disclosure. We need to define AI's roles and discern what activities should or shouldn’t require transparency. Certain uses, like editing a candidate's audio for clarity, could be harmless, while others are questionable and may demand disclosure or prohibition.

Indeed, I believe transparency is beneficial and necessary. We have the authority to address this, but starting with a public comment request is important. Gathering feedback on AI and transparency can guide us through these complexities.
I agree. Collaborating to establish clarity and transparency in AI applications is crucial. Public comments will provide insights to effectively navigate this intricate issue.

content: You are a helpful and concise assistant.

Mr. Obernolte. Right. I would agree. And let's work together to make sure that this happens. We want to make sure it happens in a way that solves the problem completely so it applies to all the channels of communication and solves the problem comprehensively in a way that doesn't devolve into different agencies arguing over does the FCC have the authority, does the FEC, has Congress delegated this authority. You This is an unedited transcript. The statements within may be inaccurate, incomplete, or misattributed to the speaker. know what, let's get the problem solved by working together.

Of course, cooperation is essential for addressing complex issues. By working together, we can ensure that solutions are thorough and don't get bogged down by jurisdictional disputes. Let's focus on the ultimate goal of solving the problem effectively across all communication channels.

Ms. Rosenworcel. And, listen, I think our public -- and I think our Notice of Proposed Rulemaking that I proposed can open up a dialogue for just that. We can in public discuss these issues; try to refine the kind of definitions that you just described, /understand what applies to Federal elections, State elections, local elections issue campaigns; and make sure that we come up with something that is simple and that people can trust; and just puts transparency front and center for the American public. I think we are all capable of doing that, and I think that is what our proposal was designed to do.

Engaging the public in these discussions is crucial. It's important to refine definitions and ensure clarity around what applies to various election contexts. Simplicity and transparency should be at the forefront, helping to build trust among citizens. Your proposal seems well-aimed at achieving these goals.
Mr. Obernolte. Let's work together on that.
I'm glad to hear your willingness to collaborate on these efforts. Joint action will greatly enhance the process.

Mr. Carr. Yeah. This is not something that we should be rushing through on the eve of an election. As you noted, it is complex. You have got deceptive deep fakes on the one hand, you have got the use of ChatGPT to run scripts for ads on the other end. This is something that Congress is taking a serious look at. It is complicated. We shouldn't be rushing this through before an election.

Absolutely, taking time to carefully consider these complex issues is essential, especially with the implications of technologies like deep fakes and AI-generated content. Rushing may lead to inadequate solutions, particularly so close to an election.

Mr. Obernolte. Commissioner Carr, I appreciate your engagement on that. My point about the different channels I stole from your testimony, so thank you very much for being engaged on that. My time has expired. Seeing no further members waiting to be recognized, I would like to thank our
I appreciate your recognition and engagement as well. It's vital to consider various communication channels in these discussions. Thank you for facilitating this important conversation.

messages.content: You are a moderator summarizing a committee meeting.

I would like to thank our witnesses for being here today. This has been a valuable exercise highlighting the importance of separation of powers and our collaborative effort. We appreciate your willingness to testify. Without objection, documents listed in the staff hearing documents will be included in the record. Members have 10 business days to submit questions for the record. Please respond promptly. Questions are due by close of business on Tuesday, July 23. The subcommittee is now adjourned.
Dear Mr. President:
Attached for your review is the Federal Communications Commission’s Annual Performance Report for Fiscal Year 1999.

We are pleased with the results of our efforts. We met or partially met sixty of our sixty-nine goals—an 87 percent success rate. In addition to our program goals, we embarked on an ambitious course of action to completely revise our Strategic Plan to ensure that our plan reflects the goals of a converging and increasingly global telecommunications industry. In redoing our plan, we reached out to industry, to state, regional, and local governments, to academe and consumer interest groups, and to our own employees to provide us with input into the plan. In August 1999, we issued a draft Strategic Plan that, I believe, provides measurable, results-oriented performance goals for the next five years.

Another notable achievement in Fiscal Year 1999 was the completion of our plan to consolidate our enforcement and consumer information activities. Historically, the FCC has been organized along the traditional lines of wire, wireless, satellite, broadcast and cable communications. This traditional structure no longer makes sense in an era when the lines dividing many communications service providers are blurring. Consolidation of our consumer information services will allow us to provide improved information services to consumers facing a bewildering choice of competing telecommunications services. Centralization of our enforcement activities will allow us to respond quickly and efficiently to questionable activities in an increasingly deregulated marketplace. Moreover, our consumer information and enforcement staff will share information that will enable us to spot trends and areas of consumer and industry concern.
The following is a letter outlining the challenges and accomplishments of the past fiscal year at the Federal Communications Commission.
I would like to discuss some of the key challenges we faced and the successes we achieved despite these obstacles. Can you share your thoughts on this?

Certainly, let's delve into it. There were several major challenges that could have potentially impeded our progress. Firstly, there was a multi-phased agency move that required us to maintain duplicate operations for a significant period. This logistical complexity especially strained our information technology resources.

Additionally, ensuring Year-2000 compliance for all our mission-critical automated processing systems was a monumental task. This involved extensive system reviews and testing to make sure everything was compliant by the end of 1999. To safeguard against potential issues, we also created a comprehensive Business Continuity and Contingency Plan for each system.

Moreover, budget constraints in Fiscal Year 1999 meant we couldn't complete certain critical network upgrades and performance goals. However, we are determined to progress on these fronts in Fiscal Year 2000, subject to securing additional funding.
It seems like a lot of effort went into maintaining operational stability. Were there any specific areas where progress was made?

Absolutely, despite these challenges, we successfully met our customer Speed of Disposal processing goals within the Authorization of Service functional area. The commitment and resilience demonstrated by our team have been exemplary, and I look forward to receiving feedback on our Annual Performance Plan.

content: You are an assistant helping to review the performance goals related to the Authorization of Service.
Objective: We will meet our established customer Speed of Disposal processing goals. 1999 Performance Goals.
Goal Met? Yes. In 1999, the FCC made significant progress in simplifying and streamlining authorization of service rules.
We will review our authorization of service rules and will simplify and streamline those authorization requests where appropriate.

In the common carrier matters, entry certification requirements under Section 214 of the Communications Act were eliminated. A streamlined authorization process for international applications was approved, qualifying approximately 99 percent of applications for 14-day processing.
In May, we adopted an order substantially revising and, in some cases, eliminating the International Settlements Policy.

Additionally, we streamlined electronic filing of 15 key broadcast application and reporting forms, which represent 88 percent of all broadcast authorization forms. A competitive bidding process was approved to replace the comparative hearing process for selecting mutually exclusive broadcast applicants.
We adopted new, simplified rules for the equipment authorization process.

This included deregulating the equipment authorization requirements for certain types of equipment and providing for electronic filing. Moreover, the FCC neared completion on the development and implementation of a Universal Licensing System, offering streamlined electronic Internet filing capabilities for most wireless services, application and tracking status information, and reducing the number of wireless application forms from 63 to five.
How was the performance measured?
Performance was measured through a review and analysis of authorization of service data and other workload reports provided by the Bureaus and Offices.
You are a report analyzer and reviewer. Your task is to assess the status and progress of various service authorization data and workload reports from different Bureaus and Offices.
Review and analyze the authorization of service data and workload reports provided by the Bureaus and Offices.

We aimed to meet 90% of our customer Speed of Disposal processing goals. This goal was partially met as the majority of license applications in all services were processed within established timeframes. However, the services where goals were not met were affected by several challenges, including the development and implementation of new electronic filing systems, Y2K compliance issues, and the technological convergence that complicated traditional licensing processes. Additionally, agency-wide efforts to reduce backlogged applications played a role.
What measures were taken to address these challenges, and what progress is anticipated?

Performance measurement was conducted through an analysis of internal workload reports. We anticipate significant progress in meeting our processing goals in Fiscal Year 2000. To address the challenges, electronic filing capabilities were provided for the CCB, MMB, IB, WTB, and OET licensing systems. Our strategy includes integrating the Wireless Telecommunications Bureau's ten licensing systems into a single, unified database to improve the Speed of Disposal and public access to the status of license applications. Additionally, efforts were made to redesign and integrate 13 Mass Media Bureau databases and to implement fully automated Equipment Authorization and Experimental Radio Service licensing systems.
What was accomplished in Fiscal Year 1999 regarding these initiatives?

In Fiscal Year 1999, we advanced our initiatives by continuing to implement electronic filing capabilities, including systems in the Common Carrier, International, Wireless Telecommunications Bureaus, and the Office of Engineering and Technology. The Wireless Telecommunications Bureau successfully deployed 7 out of 10 commercial wireless services as part of its Universal Service Licensing System.
You're an assistant providing information about the Wireless Telecommunications Bureau's licensing systems and processes.
Can you explain what the Wireless Telecommunications Bureau has done regarding commercial wireless services?

Yes, the Wireless Telecommunications Bureau has deployed 7 out of the ten commercial wireless services as part of its Universal Service Licensing System. This effort is intended to streamline the licensing process and improve accessibility for users.
What about the Mass Media Bureau's progress in electronic licensing?

The Mass Media Bureau has developed electronic licensing capabilities for all of its services and licensing systems. However, access to the public was delayed due to Y2k preparation priorities and budgetary constraints. Full implementation of these systems is dependent on adequate funding in Fiscal Year 2000.
How do you measure performance for these implementations?

Performance is measured by the number of authorization systems reengineered, the number of electronic filing systems implemented, and the effect of both on our licensees. For example, common carrier Local Access Transport Area modifications are now immediately placed on public notice and accessible electronically through the Commission’s Digital Index, with a typical comment and reply period limited to 3 weeks. An order addressing these modifications is typically issued approximately 60 days from the date of original filing.
How is the process improved for telecommunications carriers to add or discontinue lines?

Telecommunications carriers seeking to add new or discontinue old lines can obtain authority under Section 214 with no regulatory delays. On June 30, 1999, a Report and Order revised Part 63 rules eliminating the requirement to file applications for entry authority. This also entails that applications for discontinuance are granted automatically. Since these rules were implemented, no entry applications have been filed, and all but two applications for discontinuance have been allowed to become effective automatically.

messages.content: You are an FCC regulatory performance assessment assistant.
Provide a summary of the 1999 performance goals in the FCC's authorization of service.

In 1999, the FCC set performance objectives in various functional areas of service authorization. One key goal was to employ spectrum auctions to facilitate efficient licensing and promote innovative spectrum use. The agency met all Congressionally-mandated auction schedules even though there were no such mandates in 1999, conducting six auctions and awarding about 1,700 licenses totaling $640 million. Another objective was to boost competition in telecommunications by efficiently licensing competitive services. The goal of meeting 90% of customer Speed of Disposal targets was mostly met despite some services falling short due to the development of new electronic filing systems, Y2K compliance efforts, and reducing a backlog of applications. Significant progress is expected in Fiscal Year 2000 with the necessary funding.
You are a facilitator for organizational efficiency.
How is the agency addressing backlogged applications and what are the plans for Fiscal Year 2000?

The agency is implementing an agency-wide effort to eliminate backlogged applications. We expect to make significant progress in meeting our customer service goals in Fiscal Year 2000, given the funding required to continue our implementation of electronic filing systems. Performance was measured through analysis of data contained in internal workload reports.
You are a policy analyst discussing regulatory processes.
What are the objectives related to policy and rulemaking for 1999?
The objective was to restructure and streamline the FCC, eliminating outdated or redundant organizations and overlapping regulations.
Was the goal to use forbearance authority met?

Yes, the Commission issued 24 orders addressing petitions for forbearance in FY 1999. Performance was measured by review of Orders issued in connection with parties’ requests for forbearance from regulation.
How did the FCC handle the review of its functions and structures?

In Fiscal Year 1999, the FCC completed all planning for the consolidation of its enforcement and consumer information activities. This consolidation is aimed at improving efficiency and enhancing the delivery of consumer information and enforcement services to the general public and to the industry. This followed an agency-wide biennial review in Fiscal Year 1998 to eliminate, consolidate, and/or revise rules that were obsolete or outdated.

content: You are an expert on regulatory review processes and associated legal acts like the Telecommunications Act of 1996.
Can you summarize the actions taken in FY 1999 regarding regulatory streamlining by the FCC?

In Fiscal Year 1999, the FCC undertook several actions to streamline regulations and eliminate those deemed no longer necessary in the public interest. This included releasing 9 orders and 1 policy statement. Significant actions included: adopting orders to streamline the Section 214 authorization process in March 1999; revising the International Settlements Policy in May 1999; updating the settlement rate benchmark for facilities-based services on affiliated foreign routes in June 1999; and making fundamental changes to broadcast application and licensing procedures. Additionally, in August 1999, the FCC modified various ownership rules, such as the Local TV duopoly restrictions and national television ownership rule, to better align with the current marketplace.

messages.content: You are a helpful assistant.
The FCC is currently considering additional changes to its ownership rules to conform to the current marketplace as an additional implementation of the 1998 Biennial Regulatory Review.

The 1998 Biennial Regulatory Review aimed to update and modernize FCC rules to better fit the evolving telecommunications landscape. This ongoing review process helps ensure that regulations are relevant and efficient, removing outdated rules that don't serve the public interest.
You are a helpful assistant.
We will complete relocation of the FCC into a consolidated facility.

The relocation into a consolidated facility was successfully completed in May 1999. This move was part of an effort to streamline FCC operations and improve efficiency, and its success was measured by the timely completion of the relocation process.
You are a helpful assistant.
We will coordinate network disclosure reporting requirements under Section 251 and 273 of the Communications Act to avoid any duplicate or redundant disclosure regulations.

The FCC has taken steps to synchronize network disclosure reporting to eliminate redundancy. Public notices for Section 251 disclosures are issued promptly, usually within a week, with no complaints recorded about overlaps with Section 273. This coordination enhances efficiency and clarity in regulatory processes.
You are a helpful assistant.

We will review the CCB Computer III Court Remand to determine whether any of the network disclosure rules under Section 251(c)(5) duplicate or even exceed the rules established under the Computer II and Computer III decisions.

The FCC reviewed and subsequently eliminated the Computer III network disclosure rules in the Computer III Remand Order issued in July 1999. This action was part of an ongoing assessment to ensure regulatory simplicity and avoid unnecessary duplication.
You are a telecommunications regulatory expert.
What are some of the key actions taken by the FCC regarding telecommunications settlements and filings?

The FCC has taken several key actions in this area. Firstly, they have worked on privatizing the International Telecommunications Settlements process. In July 1999, they ended their role as the maritime accounting authority. They also implemented an electronic tariff filing system (ETFS) which allows incumbent local exchange carriers to file tariffs and related documents online, and other parties to access these filings. Although due to Y2K issues, a full review on whether privatization of electronic filing functions would be beneficial was not completed, the initial steps towards improving public access through technology were undertaken.
You are a telecommunications regulatory expert.
How does the FCC engage with public and regulatory partners to ensure its rules are effective and minimally burdensome?

The FCC conducts public forums and meets regularly with state regulatory partners and consumer groups to solicit input and feedback. This approach is intended to ensure that their rules are in the public interest and as unobtrusive as possible. For example, in FY 1999, they held three significant public meetings involving members from the telecommunications industry, state and local governments, and academic and organizational experts to discuss the FCC’s Draft Strategic Plan. These meetings were available both in-person and over the Internet, facilitating broader participation and feedback.

content: You are acting as a representative summarizing activities and performance goals in the telecommunications sector.

Members of the telecommunications industry, state and local government, and academic and organizational experts participated in meetings both in-person and via the Internet. The transcripts of each meeting were published online.

We held various public fora and continued our collaboration with state regulatory partners and consumer groups. We also engaged with the North American Numbering Council and the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commission through regular meetings.

FCC staff attended several meetings in preparation for the upcoming World Radiocommunications Conference. Moreover, bimonthly meetings with the Local and State Government Advisory Committee were also conducted.

Public forums addressed multiple issues including Telecommunications Relay Services implementation, proposals to streamline Part 68 terminal equipment registration, industry perspectives on cable landing license policy and procedures, and seminars on political programming rules.
Focus on the 1999 objectives related to policy and rulemaking.
In 1999, we aimed to encourage competition in the telecommunications industry through pro-competitive, deregulatory rulemakings to reduce consumer costs and increase telecommunications choices.
Was the goal of implementing local competition provisions achieved?

Yes, we successfully implemented local competition provisions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. These were executed through several Reports and Orders including the Unbundling Remand Report and Order, the Collocation Order, and the Line Sharing Order.

messages.content: You are an expert in telecommunications policy.
Please explain the key provisions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 related to competition and internet access in schools and rural areas.

The Telecommunications Act of 1996 had several key provisions aimed at promoting competition and improving internet access in schools and rural areas. Some of the main elements include the Unbundling Remand Report and Order, the Collocation Order, and the Pricing Flexibility Order, which considered regulations on CLEC access rates. Notable progress was made in Access Reform Proceedings, and audits were conducted on collocation and local number portability costs. 

For improving internet access, significant efforts were made to enhance connectivity in classrooms, libraries, and rural health facilities by the end of FY 1999. The FCC extended first-year funding for Schools and Libraries (S&L) and Rural Health Care (RHC) programs and set the second-year funding at $2.25 billion for S&L and $12 million for RHC. Simplifications were introduced to help rural health care providers receive universal service support. Additionally, a rulemaking was completed to make telecommunications services accessible to persons with disabilities under Section 255 of the Act.
The following are initiatives and actions taken related to telecommunications policies.
Can you summarize the actions taken by the FCC regarding Section 255 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996?

The FCC adopted and released an order implementing Section 255 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 to promote the accessibility of telecommunications services and equipment to persons with disabilities. They also convened a public forum on access to 711, designated as the nationwide number for Telecommunications Relay Services.
The following are updates related to telecommunications regulations.
What actions have been taken to make emergency information accessible to persons with hearing disabilities?

A draft order adopting emergency information requirements has been prepared, and final FCC action is expected by March 31, 2000. Actions are being reviewed to ensure that emergency information on cable systems is accessible to persons with hearing disabilities.
The following are updates on public safety telecommunications initiatives.
Could you elaborate on the steps taken to ensure public safety groups have adequate spectrum and advanced telecommunications equipment?

In April 1999, the FCC adopted a Memorandum Opinion and Order addressing concerns by the American National Standard Institute, allowing the Public Safety National Coordination Committee (NCC) to proceed with increased efficiency. Performance was measured by reviewing actions to ensure adequate spectrum and advanced telecommunications equipment for public safety use.
The following are updates regarding international telecommunications agreements.
What is the status of implementing the World Trade Organization Basic Services Agreement?

In March 1999, the FCC adopted an order to further streamline the Section 214 process, facilitating WTO-member nations' ability to apply for authorization to provide competitive telecommunications services to U.S. customers.
You're a knowledgeable assistant.
Can WTO-member nations apply for authorization to provide competitive telecommunications services to U.S. customers?

Yes, WTO-member nations can apply for authorization. In March 1999, the FCC adopted an order to streamline the Section 214-authorization process and foreign notifications rules, allowing most applications to provide international telecommunications services to be granted under a 14-day streamlined process, including those by foreign-owned carriers.
You're a knowledgeable assistant.
What topics were covered in regulator-to-regulator meetings?
The regulator-to-regulator meetings covered topics such as interconnection principles and establishing independent and transparent regulatory regimes.

What action was taken by the FCC in August 1999?

In August 1999, the FCC authorized certain U.S. earth stations to provide fixed-satellite services (FSS) to, from, and within the U.S. via New Skies Satellites, NV. This decision was measured by a review of actions taken to promote the implementation of the WTO Basic Services Agreement.
You're a knowledgeable assistant.
What is being done to implement an efficient, pro-competitive procedure for N11 codes?

The FCC is considering proposals from the United Way and the Department of Transportation for establishing an N11 code. Performance is measured by reviewing actions taken to implement an efficient and pro-competitive procedure for the administration of and access to N11 codes.

Inter-exchange Carrier Purchases of Switched Access Services are part of the efforts to refine pricing rules to provide increased flexibility to ILECs (Incumbent Local Exchange Carriers) in pricing interstate access. This was a part of a broader initiative to ensure that economic cost models accurately estimate the costs for providing unbundled network elements and access services.

You are a telecommunications regulatory expert.
What steps has the FCC taken towards technological innovation concerning Part 68 regulations?

The FCC initiated rulemakings to update Part 68 of the rules and regulations to incorporate technological innovations. The Notice of Proposed Rulemaking on the deregulation of Part 68-equipment registration was tentatively scheduled for consideration in March 2000. Performance was measured by reviewing actions taken to update Part 68 of the rules and regulations to ensure they remain relevant in the face of technological advancements.
You are a telecommunications regulatory expert.
What was the process for administering carrier identification codes (CIC)?

The FCC implemented procedures to administer carrier identification codes (CIC) in an efficient and nondiscriminatory manner. The conversion from three-to-four digit CIC was completed by the deadline of September 1, 1998. During this period, several waiver petitions were granted to accommodate the network plans of small carriers. The last such waiver expired on December 30, 1999, for the Virgin Islands Telephone Company. Performance was reviewed based on the actions taken to efficiently administer carrier identification codes.

Can you tell me what actions were taken to implement procedures regarding carrier identification codes and caller ID?

The existing rules concerning caller ID were refined to address consumer concerns, although only a few calls and petitions were received by the FCC on the matter. The concerns were handled as informal complaints, and further refinement was deemed unnecessary. The performance was measured through a review of consumer concerns.
You are a helpful assistant.
What actions did the FCC take regarding rural carriers and universal service high cost support certification?

The FCC decided that reform of high-cost support for rural carriers should be postponed until January 1, 2001, pending recommendations from the Joint Board and a Rural Task Force. Performance measurement involved reviewing actions taken to establish certification procedures for rural carriers.

Can you tell me about changes in the Telecommunications Relay Service Fund?

The FCC changed the cost-recovery mechanism for the TRS Fund from a gross-revenues formula to an end-user formula, as stated in the Streamlined Contributor Reporting Requirements Report and Order. This change was made in accordance with practices specified for several other funds under the Telecommunications Act of 1996. Actions were taken to streamline the TRS Fund administration procedures.
How does the FCC handle toll-free numbers?

The FCC promotes the efficient use and allocation of toll-free numbers and plans to deploy additional toll-free services. The FCC anticipated releasing a Report and Order regarding the neutral administration of toll-free numbers in April 2000. Performance was reviewed based on actions taken to promote efficiency in the use and allocation of these toll-free numbers.
What is the FCC's involvement in global communication services standard setting?

The FCC is actively participating in global standard setting for communication services. In February 1999, the FCC proposed rules to implement international arrangements for Global Mobile Personal Communications by Satellite (GMPCS) as adopted by the ITU. The proposal outlined comprehensive procedures for licensing, marking, certification, and customs treatment of GMPCS terminals, along with safeguards against potential interference to existing aeronautical services. The FCC was involved in the Telecommunication Standardization, Radio Communications, and the Telecommunication Development Sectors of the ITU, and participated in various meetings to prepare for WRC 2000.

These included MCI Telecommunication Corporation/Echostar; Lockheed Martin/Comsat; Frontier/Global Crossing; Airtouch Communications/Vodafone; AT&T/British Telecommunications; USSB/DIRECTV, and Tempo Satellite, Inc./DIRECTV Enterprises, Inc. In FY 1998, the FCC conducted an agency-wide biennial review to identify rules and regulations that could be eliminated or revised. Based on this review, in 1999, the FCC initiated rulemakings to remove obsolete or overlapping regulatory and/or reporting requirements. Action taken in common carrier issues included the release of 9 orders and 1 policy statement.

In 1999, the FCC made significant regulatory changes across different communication sectors. In common carrier issues, they released several orders and policy statements addressing obsolete matters. They revamped broadcast application and licensing processes for better usability, modifying local TV and radio/TV cross-ownership rules. Progress was also made in streamlining satellite and international application procedures, including recommendations for Direct Satellite Broadcast service rules. The Section 214 authorization process was expedited, and changes were made to the International Settlements Policy. For routine satellite earth station applications, a 35-day automatic grant period was adopted, and a settlement rate benchmark condition for affiliated foreign routes was revised. Additionally, comprehensive streamlining of wireless licensing rules was completed, focusing on Part 90 rules.

Can you provide information about the Universal Licensing System rulemaking and related performance goals for 1999?

The Universal Licensing System rulemaking issued a Memorandum Opinion and Order in June 1999. A rulemaking was also initiated to streamline Part 90 rules for private land mobile radio services. Additionally, a rulemaking was completed to simplify and streamline Part 97 Amateur Radio Service rules.
What were some of the performance goals related to enforcement in 1999, and were they met?

For 1999, one of the performance goals under the enforcement functional area was to streamline the complaints process for timely and satisfactory consumer complaint resolution. The goals included increasing the number of pending routine informal common carrier complaints disposed of by 10% and increasing the number of informal complaints served on telephone companies by 10%. However, these goals were not met due to technical problems with the automated informal complaints system, particularly issues related to Y2K compliance. Additional resources were needed to either revise or replace the current system. Efforts were made to upgrade the system, and temporary clerks were hired to assist in processing complaints.

The FCC exceeded this goal by reducing the number of active pending formal common carrier complaints by 21% over Fiscal Year 1998 levels. Performance was measured by a review and analysis of the Quarterly Workload Reports. Great job!

Additional attention is now given to this issue following the organizational restructuring by the FCC. Can you outline the FCC's 1999 objectives and performance metrics?

The FCC's 1999 objectives for the Enforcement functional area included partnering with the private sector and various government levels to address telecommunications issues affecting safety. They aimed for quick, cost-effective problem resolution that considered local interests. The performance goals included:

1. Working with federal agencies, state commissions, and the public for processing Bell Operating Company Section 271 applications. This goal was met, with performance measured by reviewing input from federal and state representatives and expeditious processing.

2. Collaborating with state regulatory commissions for federal/state audits of Regional Bell Operating Companies and other carriers. This was successful, with performance measured by actions taken in conjunction with the states.

3. Enforcing parts of the Communications Assistance to Law Enforcement Act, focusing on system security and integrity regulations.

What are the FCC's responsibilities under the Enforcement Act?
The FCC oversees the implementation of the Commission’s system security and integrity regulations and adjudicates petitions promptly as part of its responsibilities under the Enforcement Act.

What is CALEA Section 201?
CALEA Section 201, codified as 47 USC § 229, requires the FCC to promulgate and enforce regulations concerning electronic surveillance of telecommunications carriers.

Has the FCC issued any directives regarding electronic surveillance?
Yes, in 1999, the FCC issued two reports and Orders detailing specific requirements for electronic surveillance.

How does the FCC measure its performance in enforcing system security and integrity regulations?
Performance is measured by reviewing actions taken to implement and enforce the FCC’s system security and integrity regulations under CALEA.
