The following conversation discusses the Wireless Emergency Alerts system and a recent proposal by the FCC.
How does WEA work?

The Wireless Emergency Alerts (WEA) system is designed to enhance public safety by sending geographically targeted alerts to compatible mobile devices. These alerts notify the public about imminent threats to safety, such as dangerous weather or missing persons. Government officials can target specific geographic areas, like lower Manhattan in New York, to ensure that only those in the affected area receive the alert. Established by the Warning, Alert and Response Network (WARN) Act in 2008 and operational since 2012, WEA is a collaborative effort involving the Federal Emergency Management Agency, the FCC, and the U.S. wireless industry. Participation is voluntary for wireless companies.
How does WEA work?

Authorized national, state or local government authorities send alerts regarding public safety emergencies such as severe weather, missing children, or the need to evacuate using WEA. Authorized public safety officials send WEA alerts through FEMA's Integrated Public Alert and Warning System (IPAWS) to participating wireless carriers, which then push the alerts to compatible mobile devices in the affected area.
Who receives the alerts?

The alerts are broadcast to the geographic area affected by an emergency. This means that if an alert is sent to a zone in New York, WEA-capable mobile devices in that zone can receive the alert, even if they are roaming or visiting from another state. In other words, a customer visiting from Chicago would be able to receive alerts in New York so long as the person has a WEA-enabled mobile device in the alert zone.
How much do consumers pay to receive WEA?
Alerts are free. Customers do not pay to receive WEA.
Do consumers have to sign up to receive alerts?

Consumers do not need to sign up for this service. WEA allows government officials to send emergency alerts to all subscribers with WEA-capable devices if their wireless carrier participates in the program.
What alerts does WEA deliver?
WEA alerts only cover critical emergency situations. Consumers can receive four types of alerts: Participating carriers may allow subscribers to block all but National Alerts.
What do consumers experience when they receive a WEA?

A WEA alert appears on the screen of the recipient's handset as a text-like message. The alert is accompanied by a unique attention signal and vibration, which is particularly helpful to people with hearing or vision-related disabilities.
Are consumers able to receive WEAs on a prepaid phone?
Are consumers able to receive WEAs on a prepaid phone?

Yes. Consumers with prepaid phones can receive WEAs as long as their provider has decided to participate in WEA and the customer has a WEA-enabled device. These consumers receive the alerts just as customers with postpaid, monthly service do.
Does WEA track my location?
No. WEA is not designed to and does not track the location of anyone receiving a WEA alert.
Are WEAs text messages?
No. Many providers have chosen to transmit WEAs using a technology that is separate and different from voice calls and SMS text messages.
Do consumers need a new phone or a smart phone to receive alerts?

Consumers should check with their wireless carrier regarding the availability of WEA-capable handsets. In addition, CTIA, a wireless trade association, publishes lists of WEA-capable phones offered by the largest wireless providers.
Is WEA available everywhere?

Participation in WEA by wireless carriers is widespread but voluntary. Some carriers may offer WEA over all or parts of their service areas or over all or only some of their wireless devices. Other carriers may not offer WEA at all. Even if you have a WEA-enabled device, you would not receive WEAs in a service area where the provider is not offering WEA or if your device is roaming on a provider network that does not support the WEA service. Consumers should check with their wireless carriers to determine the extent to which they are offering WEA.
Can consumers block WEAs?

Partially. Participating wireless carriers may offer subscribers with WEA-capable handsets the ability to block alerts involving imminent threats to safety of life and/or AMBER Alerts. Consumers cannot block National Alerts.
Why can't consumers block National Alerts?
In passing the WARN Act, Congress allowed participating wireless carriers to offer subscribers the capability to block all WEAs except National Alerts.
How will subscribers know whether their carrier offers WEA?
The FCC requires all wireless carriers that do not participate in WEA to notify customers. Consumers should check with their wireless carriers to determine the extent to which they are offering WEA.
My friend just received a WEA over her cell phone, but I did not. We are in the same location. Why didn't I receive a WEA?

To receive a WEA message, your handset must be WEA-capable, switched on, not on "airplane mode," and in the vicinity of and receiving service from a cell tower of a wireless carrier that participates in WEA.
Some participating carriers may offer WEA on some, but not all, of their mobile devices. Consumers should check with their wireless carriers to find out if their cell phone is WEA-capable.
How geographically precise is WEA?

WEA geographic precision is continuously improving. When the WEA program launched, participating wireless providers were generally required to send the alerts to a geographic area no larger than the county or counties affected by the emergency. Next, beginning in 2017, participating wireless providers were required to transmit alerts to a geographic area that best approximated the area affected by the emergency, even if it was smaller than a county. Now, as of December 2019, participating wireless providers must geographically target alerts to technologically compatible phones even more: they must deliver the alerts to the area specified by the alert originator with no more than a 1/10 of a mile overshoot.

What is the purpose of the MEP event code?

The purpose of the MEP event code is to help law enforcement agencies issue timely alerts about missing and endangered adults who fall outside the criteria for an AMBER Alert, in line with the Ashanti Alert Act. It aims to increase public attention and aid in locating missing persons.

content: You are an expert on the Federal Communications Commission's processes for public participation in rulemaking.
How does the FCC involve the public in developing rules and policies?

The FCC involves the public in developing rules and policies through a process called 'notice and comment' rulemaking. This process involves giving the public notice when the FCC is considering adopting or modifying rules on a particular subject and seeking public comments. The comments received are then considered in developing the final rules. This participation allows the public to influence telecommunications and broadcast-related issues.
What happens when a new telecommunications law is enacted by Congress?

When Congress enacts a new law affecting telecommunications, the FCC initiates a proceeding to create the rules and policies required by the new law. This ensures that the commission's regulations align with legislative changes. What are the FCC's ex parte rules and how do they affect participation in FCC proceedings?

The FCC's ex parte rules are designed to ensure that all participants in an FCC proceeding have a fair opportunity to be informed of the views presented by others. An ex parte presentation is any written or oral communication by an outside party to the Commission or any Commission staff involved in decision making, addressing the merits or outcome of a proceeding without being served to all involved parties (if written) or without all parties being given advance notice (if oral). These rules determine whether and under what circumstances ex parte presentations may be made to the FCC. Most rulemaking proceedings are 'permit but disclose,' allowing ex parte presentations as long as copies (or written summaries of oral presentations) are filed in the proceeding's record. However, certain proceedings, such as those designated for hearings and licensing proceedings, are 'restricted,' meaning that ex parte communications are prohibited unless specifically exempted.

content: You are an assistant that provides detailed information about the FCC's rulemaking processes.
Can you explain the FCC's process for issuing new rules or making changes to existing ones?

Certainly! The FCC follows a structured process to issue new rules or modify existing ones.

The process often begins with a Notice of Inquiry (NOI), where the FCC gathers facts and information on a specific topic to determine if further action is necessary. This stage involves asking questions about the topic and gathering public comments.

Once the FCC has enough information, it proceeds with a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM). This is where the FCC proposes new rules or changes and seeks public comment on these proposals. A summary of the NPRM is published in the Federal Register, including deadlines for public commentary.

Following the comment period, the Commission reviews all feedback received. If further comments are needed, a Further Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (FNPRM) may be issued. Ultimately, the FCC will release a Report and Order (R&O) to adopt the final rules based on all submissions.

Additionally, the FCC can issue other documents like a Memorandum Opinion and Order (MO&O) for external requests such as petitions for waiver or forbearance.
What happens when a Petition for Rulemaking is filed?

When a Petition for Rulemaking is filed, it suggests new rules or changes to existing ones. The FCC will issue a Public Notice (PN) seeking public comment on the petition. The public generally has 30 days to file their comments, unless specified otherwise in the PN.

After reviewing these comments, the FCC may adopt the proposed changes through a Report and Order (R&O), initiate a Notice of Inquiry (NOI) to gather more information, or proceed with a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) to seek further public input on the proposed changes. All documents related to the petition process are available in the FCC's Electronic Comment Filing System (ECFS) and for public inspection at the FCC's Reference Information Center in Washington, DC.

Can you explain what an R&O is and how it relates to rule changes?

An R&O, or a Report and Order, adopts new rules, amends existing ones, or states that there will be no changes. Sometimes the FCC issues a combined R&O and FNPRM (Further Notice of Proposed Rulemaking). The FCC publishes summaries of FNPRMs and R&Os in the Federal Register and states when a rule change will become effective.
What can parties do if they disagree with the FCC's ruling in a R&O?

If a party disagrees with the FCC's ruling in a R&O, they can file a Petition for Reconsideration within 30 days of the date the summary of the R&O appears in the Federal Register. This petition formally requests the FCC to modify its ruling.

Your submission, including personal information, may be shared within the FCC as well as with other Federal or State agencies, or others if necessary to address matters raised in your submission as allowed by the Commission's systems of records or as otherwise required or authorized by statute.

What is the role of the Federal Communications Commission?

The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) regulates interstate and international communications by radio, television, wire, satellite, and cable in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories. It is an independent U.S. government agency overseen by Congress, and it is the primary authority in the United States for communications law, regulation, and technological innovation.
How is the FCC structured in terms of leadership?

The FCC is directed by five commissioners who are appointed by the President of the United States and confirmed by the U.S. Senate. The president selects one of the commissioners to serve as chairman. There are restrictions on the political party representation of these commissioners; only three can be from the same political party. Commissioners, including the chairman, serve five-year terms, except when filling an unexpired term.
Can FCC commissioners have financial interests in communications businesses?
No, FCC commissioners cannot have a financial interest in any commission-related business. This ensures impartiality and fairness in their regulatory duties.
Where can I find the FCC's rules and regulations?

What is the Federal Advisory Committee Act?

content: You are a knowledgeable assistant providing information on IT system vulnerabilities and public safety implications.
What happened with the recent CrowdStrike update?

On July 19, 2024, CrowdStrike, a U.S. cybersecurity firm, released a software update that inadvertently caused certain systems to crash. This disrupted services across industries such as airlines, banks, hospitals, government agencies, and public safety systems. The issue stemmed from a defect in a content update on Microsoft Windows operating systems and was not due to a cyberattack.
How did this incident affect public safety systems?

Public safety agencies using CrowdStrike's cybersecurity software experienced significant disruptions. This included some 911 systems, police and fire agency systems, and other networks integral to emergency alerting. The incident also affected federal agencies supporting public safety and emergency response operations.
Can you give an example of how specific areas were impacted?

In Phoenix, AZ, the police department reported that their computerized 911 dispatch system was affected by the CrowdStrike update. While the 911 centers could receive voice calls, their computer systems were not operational, impacting their ability to dispatch services efficiently.
You are a helpful assistant.
What were the impacts of the system outage on public safety departments?

The system outage had various impacts on public safety departments across different locations:

- In Phoenix, AZ, the police department's 911 dispatch center was affected, causing a manual recording of caller information instead of using the computerized system.
- In Portland, OR, the city's Bureau of Emergency Communication had to take calls manually for their 911 center due to the affected CAD system.
- In Alaska, state troopers announced issues with 911 systems and provided alternative phone numbers.
- In Middletown, OH, the police issued a notice about their inability to receive 911 calls, offering alternative numbers.

Some jurisdictions did not report impacts on their 911 services, while other areas experienced issues beyond 911:

- In Columbus, OH, police could not access data from vehicle terminals, affecting law enforcement data and license plate information, and firefighters couldn't receive dispatch information in vehicles.
- In Ocean City, MD, fire alarms that contact the fire department automatically were reportedly affected.

Federal support agencies like the Department of Homeland Security experienced login difficulties on desktop computers but managed to work around them.

messages.content: You are a helpful assistant.

A Department of Homeland Security (DHS) manager reported that some staff encountered issues logging into desktop computers but were able to work through phones, virtual desktop, or web-based applications.
Thank you for the update. It’s good that staff could continue working through alternative methods.

DHS’s Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) reported some issues with its systems, but an agency spokesperson said, “there are no impacts to FEMA’s critical or immediate lifesaving and life-sustaining operations. There is also no evidence of any data loss.”
It’s reassuring to know that there was no impact on critical operations or evidence of data loss at FEMA.

FEMA’s Integrated Public Alert and Warning System (IPAWS) and the Emergency Alert System were reportedly working normally; however, some broadcasters whose stations may play a role in distribution of alerts and warnings were affected.
The core alert systems being operational is crucial, though it's worth noting the impact on broadcasters involved in alert distribution.

Public safety agencies rely on commercial telecommunication networks as an additional means of communications for prioritization of calls for officials, and for 911 calling and emergency alerting. Telecommunication networks seemingly were not affected by the incident.
That’s a relief. The reliability of telecommunications networks is vital for emergency communications.
IT systems of some telecom providers who use CrowdStrike’s service were affected, leading to some disruption of business operations and customer service, but networks remained operational.
While it's unfortunate that some IT systems were disrupted, the key is that telecommunication networks continued to function properly.

The incident was similar to a February 22, 2024, outage of the AT&T wireless network in that both were caused by a faulty software update, and both affected public safety systems. The events were different in that AT&T was updating its own network, whereas CrowdStrike—a third-party vendor that provides cybersecurity services to companies and government agencies—was updating its client-end software on its customers’ computers.
Understanding the nuances between these incidents is important for developing future strategies to handle similar events more effectively.
You are providing information about cybersecurity in telecommunications.
Can you explain the significance of IP-based networks in modern telecommunications?

IP-based networks have revolutionized modern telecommunications by enabling interconnectivity between a multitude of networks, thus creating the global internet. This connectivity allows diverse devices like smartphones and smart TVs to seamlessly communicate. However, while facilitating enhanced communication, the proliferation of IP-based networks has introduced new cybersecurity risks, as virtually anyone can now access these networks.
You are discussing the implications of cybersecurity in the context of telecommunications and public safety.
How are public safety sectors addressing the shift to IP-based networks?

Public safety sectors are transitioning to IP-based networks and software-defined networks to improve network management, performance, and interconnectivity. For example, Next Generation 911 (NG911) implements advanced features like text-to-911 and multimedia communications, which enhance call routing and location-finding capabilities. This interconnectivity increases redundancy and resiliency but also introduces new vulnerabilities, including increased cyber risks. Organizations often manage these risks internally or by using third-party vendors like CrowdStrike to protect their systems.

content: You are discussing the impacts of a third-party cybersecurity vendor incident involving CrowdStrike.
Can you explain the potential risks associated with relying on third-party vendors for IT services, particularly in critical areas?

Certainly. Depending on third-party vendors for critical IT services can introduce risks such as outages that affect multiple entities simultaneously. For example, if a vendor like CrowdStrike, a global cybersecurity firm, experiences an outage or releases a software update, it could impact not only general services but also crucial public safety systems. This highlights the importance of having robust backup protocols to maintain service continuity during such disruptions.
What steps did the Executive Branch take in response to the CrowdStrike incident?

The Executive Branch, including the White House and DHS's Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), assessed the impact on federal IT, critical infrastructure, and public safety systems. CISA worked closely with CrowdStrike and other partners, including federal, state, local, tribal, territorial entities, and international allies, to evaluate impacts and support remediation. The FCC also collaborated with federal agencies to address disruptions and assess their impact on vital services like 911 systems.
How has Congress reacted to this incident?

Several Members of Congress and committees have acknowledged and responded to the CrowdStrike incident, recognizing its implications and potentially looking into measures to mitigate similar risks in the future.

messages.content: You are a Congressional policy advisor.
What has been the Congressional response to the CrowdStrike incident?

Members and committees, including the chair and a subcommittee chair of the House Committee on Homeland Security, have written a letter requesting that CrowdStrike schedule a hearing with the subcommittee. Additionally, some Members of the House Oversight and Accountability and the House Energy and Commerce Committees have reportedly requested separate briefings from CrowdStrike.
You are a Congressional policy advisor.
What considerations might Congress have in terms of assessing risks related to public safety agencies?

Congress may consider assessing and addressing potential risks associated with public safety agencies, especially as funding for the transition to NG911 is considered. For example, Congress could direct the Department of Homeland Security's Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) to work with public and private partners to identify risks to public safety systems, recommend mitigation methods, and establish best practices to prevent outages. Additionally, the National Institute of Standards and Technology could be tasked with developing recommendations for minimum standards for software testing and release protocols. Congress may also prioritize funding for infrastructure resiliency, including backup systems for public safety.
You are a Congressional policy advisor.
What limitations does the FCC face in regulating internet service providers concerning public safety communications?

While the FCC regulates telecommunications service providers and requires them to report outages affecting 911 services, its regulatory authority over internet service providers, which support public safety communications such as 911 and alerting systems, is limited. The FCC has sought public comments on a proposal to require broadband internet providers to report outages during disasters, emphasizing public safety dependencies on the internet. Congress may need to consider policies ensuring that internet outages, similar to telecommunications outages, are reported and communicated to public safety system operators in a timely manner.
You are a helpful assistant.
What are some policies for ensuring internet outages are reported to public safety systems?

Policies for ensuring internet outages are timely reported to public safety systems include requirements for telecommunication companies to promptly inform 911 centers, alerting agencies, police, and fire departments. This communication ensures that public safety systems remain operational and can continue to serve the community effectively during an outage.
You are a helpful assistant.
What is the primary use of emergency communication systems?

Emergency communication systems are primarily used to facilitate communication between first responders and other emergency personnel during daily operations and large-scale disasters. They also allow communication between the public and response agencies by receiving emergency calls and providing assistance.

Can 911 systems send text messages to responders?
No, current 911 systems are not able to send text messages to first responders in the field.

What is FirstNet?

FirstNet is the nationwide public safety broadband network currently under deployment. It is scheduled for completion in 2022 and will enable response agencies at all government levels to communicate via voice and data, including text and videos.
You are a helpful assistant.
Why is interoperability a concern for emergency communication systems?

Interoperability is a concern for emergency communication systems because these systems often rely on different technologies that may not be compatible, hindering effective communication and coordination during emergencies. For example, local police and fire agencies may use various radio technologies that connect responders within their agency but may not be interoperable with surrounding systems.
You are an expert in emergency communication systems.
How are federal, state, and local public safety agencies improving their communication systems?

Public safety agencies are investing in Internet Protocol (IP)-based technologies to improve their communications, coordination, and response capabilities. The federal government has developed an IP-based national alerting system that enables authorized agencies to send alerts through multiple channels. Additionally, there is an investment in FirstNet, a nationwide seamless, IP-based, high-speed mobile communications network that enhances communication among public safety agencies. Furthermore, there is an interest in upgrading 911 systems to next-generation IP-based systems to facilitate data sharing and system interconnection.
You are an expert in emergency communication systems.
What are the opportunities and challenges with new emergency communication technologies?

As emergency communications systems converge towards a common IP-based platform, several opportunities and challenges arise. Advancements in geolocation technologies make it easier to locate 911 callers, though integrating these into legacy systems can be difficult. While advancements in alerting help officials send alerts to mobile phones more effectively, some individuals still depend on landline phones for communication. Interconnecting systems can improve information sharing but also poses challenges regarding privacy and data security across multiple networks. Furthermore, the creation of nationwide systems may necessitate new policies for integrating new technologies, collaborative planning, and cross-governmental training. The migration to new technologies is expensive, and not all jurisdictions may be able to afford the costs.

content: You are a helpful assistant.

The 116th Congress may continue its oversight of the effectiveness of emergency communications before, during, and after natural or man-made disasters (e.g., hurricanes, wildfires), and the roles and responsibilities of federal, state, and local agencies, and private telecommunications providers during response.

Indeed, examining such roles and responsibilities is crucial to ensuring an efficient response during emergencies. Effective communication systems are vital for coordinating resources and aiding disaster-affected communities efficiently.

Congress may also examine the effectiveness of federal programs established to promote and support emergency communications, including the National 9-1-1 Program, First Responder Network Authority (FirstNet), Integrated Public Alert and Warning System (IPAWS), and the Emergency Communications Division in CISA.

Evaluating these programs allows Congress to identify strengths and areas for improvement, ensuring that emergency communications systems are robust, reliable, and accessible to all levels of government. Such oversight can enhance preparedness and response efforts against various threats and disasters.

messages.content: You are a helpful assistant.
Tell me about federal initiatives regarding emergency communications.

The government has several initiatives to support emergency communications. Federal grant programs play a significant role in funding these efforts. Additionally, Congress may focus on the activities of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), specifically the Public Safety and Homeland Security Bureau (PSHSB). This bureau is responsible for administering FCC policies related to emergency communications, which include rules for carriers supporting 911 services, the state and local use of 911 fees, public safety spectrum, public alerts, disaster management, and the reporting and restoration efforts of private network outages.

content: You are a specialized AI developed to provide insights on policy reports, particularly those concerning aviation and telecommunications.
Could you summarize the key concerns regarding the rollout of 5G wireless networks in relation to aviation?

The rollout of 5G wireless networks in the U.S. has raised concerns among aviation operators because certain mid-band or C-band 5G signals could potentially interfere with aircraft radio altimeters. This led the FAA to issue alerts about possible safety risks and resulted in telecommunications companies delaying 5G service near airports to allow further assessment and mitigation of any interference with flight operations.
What measures have been taken to address these aviation concerns?

In response to the concerns, the FAA has asked aircraft operators for data, educated pilots on potential disruptions, and restricted certain flight procedures as safety precautions. Telecommunications companies, at the request of FAA, Department of Transportation, the White House, and members of Congress, agreed to delay the 5G rollout near airports until July 2022 to prevent disruptions while further assessments are conducted.
Explain the difference in how 5G networks are rolled out globally in terms of radiofrequency spectrum allocation.

Globally, 5G networks are being installed with varying frequency band assignments. While low-band and high-band frequencies aren't a major concern for aviation, the mid-band or C-band frequencies, around 3 to 5 GHz, have raised alarms due to potential interference with aviation equipment like radio altimeters. For instance, Europe allocates 3.4 to 3.8 GHz for C-band 5G, while Japan uses a range of 3.4 to 4.1 GHz.

messages.content: You are an aviation and telecommunications expert.
Can you explain the concerns about 5G interference with radio altimeters?

Certainly! The concerns stem from potential interference between 5G transmissions and radio altimeters used in aviation. Radio altimeters operate in a frequency range between 4.2 GHz and 4.4 GHz to measure aircraft altitude. The proximity of 5G frequencies, especially those allocated around 3.7 to 3.98 GHz in the U.S., raises concerns that these could interfere with altimeter signals, affecting systems that guide landings and obstacle clearances, particularly under low-visibility conditions.
The system is designed to provide vertical guidance for pilots below 200 feet in low-visibility conditions when they cannot clearly see the runway.
Are such systems available on all aircraft?
While these capabilities are essential for all-weather commercial flight operations, they are not commonly found on small general aviation aircraft.
When did the FAA first raise concerns about 5G and aviation safety?
The FAA, along with aviation regulators from other countries, first raised concerns about wireless deployments in the C-band in 2015.
What were they particularly worried about?
They cautioned that 5G signals transmitted on nearby frequencies could potentially interfere with radio altimeters, especially if high-powered 5G base stations are placed close to airport runways.
Are radio altimeters equipped to handle nearby 5G signals?

Although not required by regulation, most radio altimeters currently in use have mask filters to block signals on nearby frequencies that could be mistaken for reflected radio altimeter signals. However, it is uncertain whether these filters will adequately block more powerful 5G signals in all cases.
What did the RTCA study find regarding 5G interference?

A study by RTCA, an aviation industry technical advisory group, concluded that expected interference levels from fundamental 5G emissions in the 3.7-3.98 GHz range and spurious or stray 5G emissions that bleed over into the 4.2-4.4 GHz band were likely to exceed safe interference limits for all envisioned 5G transmitter configurations across all categories of airplanes and helicopters equipped with radio altimeters.
How did the FCC respond to the RTCA's findings?

The FCC countered that the RTCA findings assume a worst-case scenario, and that alternative testing found that FCC-mandated protections, including limits on the strength of 5G signals and 220 MHz of spectral separation between 5G signals and radio altimeters, would mitigate the potential interference.
You are a helpful assistant.
Can you explain the FCC's stance on 5G and radio altimeter interference?

The FCC has mandated protections to mitigate potential interference of 5G signals with radio altimeters. This includes limits on 5G signal strength and 220 MHz of spectral separation between 5G signals and radio altimeters. The FCC contends that properly engineered radio equipment should not be prone to harmful interference from 5G signals.
You are a helpful assistant.
What actions were taken by telecommunications providers regarding the 5G rollout?

Telecommunications providers voluntarily delayed the launch of 5G from early December 2021 to January 2022. This was done to give the FAA more time to address concerns regarding radio altimeter interference. Additionally, providers agreed to delay activation of 5G transmitters near airports until July 5, 2022, creating temporary buffer zones to mitigate potential risks.
You are a helpful assistant.
What were the FAA's initial actions concerning 5G deployment at airports?

In response to potential interference concerns with radio altimeters, the FAA initially restricted the use of approach procedures and automated landing system operations at 88 airports where C-band 5G signals could pose a risk. This was part of precautionary measures as the 5G deployment was set to launch in early January 2022.
You are a helpful assistant.
How did the 5G rollout affect airlines, especially regarding flight operations?

Despite the establishment of temporary 5G buffer zones around U.S. airports, concerns about potential low-visibility operation disruptions led some airlines, including international ones, to cancel flights and modify services in January 2022. This was due to continued uncertainty over 5G interference.
You are a helpful assistant.
Can you tell me about the measures taken by different countries regarding 5G and aviation safety?

Sure! Various countries have implemented different measures to address the concerns of 5G interference with aviation safety. In Canada, there have been restrictions on installing 5G transmitters near airports. Europe, differing from the U.S., hasn't faced similar aviation concerns because the approved frequencies are well-separated from radio altimeter bands. Countries like France have mandated additional mitigation measures such as reducing power output of 5G towers, restricting 5G antennas' placement near airports, and tilting antennas downwards to avoid interference. In Japan, 5G transmitters are required to be stationed at least 200 meters away from airport approaches due to even closer frequency allocations to altimeters than in the U.S.
You are a helpful assistant.
What is the current situation with radio altimeter systems and 5G interference?

As of late January 2022, the FAA has provisionally approved roughly 90% of the U.S. commercial airline fleet equipped with radio altimeters to conduct low-visibility landings at airports with nearby 5G towers. However, the FAA is working with industry groups to develop new minimum operational performance standards for future radio altimeters to prevent interference from 5G. Once these standards are established, manufacturers can produce units that are not prone to C-band 5G impacts. Replacing radio altimeters may be costly for aircraft operators, including the military, potentially leading them to seek federal relief for upgrade expenses.
You are a helpful assistant.
How are medical helicopters affected by 5G interference?

Helicopters responding to medical emergencies rely on radio altimeters when landing to pick up patients. The FAA has granted temporary regulatory relief from radio altimeter requirements for medical helicopters conducting night vision goggle operations, provided ground observers guide pilots regarding terrain and obstacle clearance via radio. This exemption expires in 2024, and at that point, medical helicopters may also need upgraded radio altimeters to prevent 5G interference.
You are a helpful assistant.
What are the lingering policy implications of the 5G rollout in relation to aviation safety?

The ongoing concerns over potential aviation safety impacts from the 5G rollout in the United States highlight several broader policy implications. These include the need for improved coordination between the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, which represents federal agency spectrum concerns to the FCC. Additionally, the FAA's relationship with other regulatory agencies such as the FCC is crucial, as is its capacity to address complex challenges arising from the proliferation of wireless technologies in an evolving technical landscape that impacts aviation operations.

content: You are a helpful assistant.
Can you tell me about the impact of Hurricane Helene on cell phone services?

On September 26, 2024, Hurricane Helene made landfall near Perry, Florida, causing significant damage to personal property and critical infrastructure, including communication networks. The impact spread across Florida, Alabama, Georgia, the Carolinas, Tennessee, and Virginia. A week after the storm, some counties continued to experience cell site outages despite repairs in many areas.
What are some of the challenges faced in restoring cell services after Hurricane Helene?

The challenges in restoring cell services included damaged infrastructure like roads, which inhibited access to cell sites, damage to cell towers and fiber lines connecting the sites to networks, and a lack of power to cell sites, which hindered permanent restoration efforts.
What role does the federal government have in restoring cell services after such disasters?

While wireless networks are privately owned and network owners are responsible for repairs, the federal government, through FEMA, may deploy communication assets to support restoration efforts when authorized.

messages.content: You are an expert on federal disaster response and communication coordination.
What happens when FEMA is authorized to respond to a disaster?

When authorized, FEMA deploys communication assets to support federal, state, local, tribal, and territorial response efforts. This could involve deploying mobile assets to assist emergency managers and coordinating with the private sector to restore private networks, such as coordinating debris removal to enable access to cell sites and sharing information on power restoration.
How does the FCC assist during disasters?

The FCC monitors the status of commercial networks and provides updates to government officials and the public on the communications network status, outages, and restoration efforts. It requires providers to report on their network status during disasters through systems like the Disaster Information Reporting System (DIRS).
Can you explain the Disaster Information Reporting System?

DIRS is a web-based system that allows providers to report their network status during disasters. The FCC activates DIRS in anticipation of or in response to disasters and announces this through public notices and emails. Providers are required to submit daily reports on network status, and the data is shared with federal emergency management officials, designated state agencies, and other government bodies involved in public safety. The FCC also publishes aggregated outage data for public access.
What is the Mandatory Disaster Response Initiative?

The Mandatory Disaster Response Initiative (MDRI) is an FCC policy that can be activated for facilities-based mobile wireless providers in certain geographic areas after a disaster. As of June 2022, this initiative was formalized in a Report and Order, transitioning from a voluntary measure to a mandatory one for better coordinated disaster response.
You are a knowledgeable resource about communication policies during disasters.
Can you tell me about how wireless service providers coordinate in the aftermath of a disaster?

In the aftermath of a disaster, wireless service providers follow certain rules set by the FCC to enhance communication coordination. This includes providing reasonable roaming when feasible, establishing mutual aid agreements with other providers, enhancing municipal preparedness, and increasing public awareness. The coordination framework is activated during emergencies or disasters by authorized entities like FEMA or through state requests under certain conditions.
You are knowledgeable about disaster response planning and coordination among agencies.
What steps were taken by wireless providers and the government before Hurricane Helene?

Before Hurricane Helene made landfall, the U.S. government and private telecommunication providers began early preparations. FEMA actively prepared and pre-staged resources to support state and local efforts. Both government and private sectors worked together to protect and restore communications infrastructure in anticipation of the hurricane.
You are a helpful assistant.

On September 24, 2024, FEMA announced that it was actively preparing and pre-staging resources to support state and local government response for Hurricane Helene. This included Mobile Emergency Restoration of Cell Phone Services (MERS), which encompasses mobile emergency communications facilities and incident teams.
What did the FCC do in response to Hurricane Helene?

On September 25, 2024, the FCC announced that it was activating DIRS and MDRI ahead of the hurricane at the request of the State of Florida and in coordination with the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and FEMA, which are ESF-2 coordinators. The activation was for select counties in Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, and South Carolina. This required providers to report outages and enable roaming across networks, coordinate with each other and with state and local agencies, and keep stakeholders and consumers informed of status and restoration efforts.
What actions did private telecommunication providers take in preparation for Hurricane Helene?

Private telecommunication providers like AT&T, Verizon, and T-Mobile took several actions to prepare for the hurricane. They fortified their networks by refueling generators and providing backup batteries at cell sites and switching centers. Additionally, they prepositioned mobile assets such as satellite cells on light trucks and wheels, and deployed teams to the region. These providers coordinated with state and local governments and their public safety customers, and were ready to receive requests for assistance. They also prepared and pre-staged equipment for deployment and offered preparedness guidance to consumers.
You are a helpful assistant.
Can you tell me how the FCC prepared for Hurricane Helene?

The FCC was involved in preparing and pre-staging equipment for deployment. They provided preparedness guidance to consumers and reminded public safety, national security, and emergency preparedness personnel enrolled in Priority Telecommunication Services about the services available to them. This program prioritizes public safety communications on wireline and wireless networks and the restoration and provisioning of communication assets. They began tracking outages and posted the first communications status report on September 26, 2024, before the hurricane made landfall.
What actions did the FCC take during and after Hurricane Helene?

On September 27, 2024, the FCC expanded the activation area to include more counties in South Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia. They started issuing daily communications status reports detailing cell site outages in each affected state and county, and tracked the percentage of cell sites down during the DIRS activation period.
How did the FCC handle cell site outages during Hurricane Helene?

The FCC coordinated with wireless service providers who reported network outages both to the FCC and on their websites. Providers responded to public safety agency requests and in some areas enabled roaming. On September 30, 2024, the FCC announced the deactivation of certain measures as the situation improved.
What actions did the FCC take in response to the telecommunications outages caused by the hurricane in 2024?

The FCC took several actions in response to the telecommunications outages caused by the hurricane in 2024. They announced the deactivation of DIRS and MDRI for certain counties on September 30, 2024, while retaining DIRS reporting and MDRI coordination in others. They also responded to requests from public safety agencies and enabled roaming in some areas. Additionally, the FCC waived eligibility requirements under its Lifeline program to offer discounted phones and broadband services to affected individuals. They provided continuous reports on outages and granted SpaceX and T-Mobile special temporary authority for using Starlink direct-to-cell satellite services in certain areas to support emergency alerting. Furthermore, in North Carolina, FEMA deployed Starlink satellite systems in each county emergency operations center to aid communications.
How did the major telecommunications providers respond to the damage caused by the storm?

Major telecommunications providers such as Verizon, AT&T, and T-Mobile took several measures to respond to the damage caused by the storm. Verizon and AT&T reported that they had restored 60% of their sites impacted by the storm and continued to deploy temporary cell sites for communications. T-Mobile stated that most of their sites in West Virginia and Georgia had been restored, while in the Carolinas, where access remained a challenge, restoration continued. Providers continued to supply batteries and fuel to generators in areas without power. Where fiber lines were damaged, they deployed mobile assets like satellite cell on wheels and microwave solutions to temporarily restore networks. Additionally, AT&T, Verizon, and T-Mobile offered charging stations and Wi-Fi in some areas to aid in the recovery efforts.
What temporary measures did the FCC implement to assist affected areas during the outages?

To assist affected areas during the outages, the FCC implemented several temporary measures. They granted SpaceX and T-Mobile special temporary authority for utilizing Starlink direct-to-cell satellite services in certain areas to support emergency alerting. Additionally, they waived eligibility requirements under their Lifeline program, allowing affected individuals to receive discounted phones and broadband services. They also coordinated with telecommunications providers to ensure the deployment of temporary solutions like mobile assets and cell sites to restore communications in the impacted regions.
What ongoing challenges were faced in the Carolinas after the storm?

In the Carolinas, ongoing challenges after the storm included limited access which hampered restoration efforts. Telecommunications companies faced difficulties in restoring networks fully due to these access issues. Despite most areas showing signs of recovery, certain regions required continued deployment of solutions such as temporary cell sites and mobile assets like satellite cells on wheels to maintain communication. Power outages also persisted, requiring providers to supply batteries and fuel for generators to keep communications systems operational.
You are a helpful assistant.

Congress may wish to explore potential lessons learned from implementation of the rule during Hurricane Helene, especially as implementing the rule relates to preparedness, coordination, and roaming. In the past, Members have been interested in expanding outage reporting to include broadband outages (H.R. 8178, 117th Congress), and the FCC has sought comment on the issue. Congress may consider changes to outage reporting. Previous Congresses also have considered legislation to improve resiliency and redundancy of cell networks by mandating or subsidizing backup power to each cell site (S. 1506, 117th Congress). While such investments could strengthen resiliency, provision of backup power sources could increase costs for providers and consumers. Finally, Congress could consider advantages and disadvantages of expanded use of and federal support for advanced technologies, including drones and satellite technologies in rural regions to support communications.

Congress has various options to enhance telecommunications resilience during emergencies. Implementing strategies from past hurricanes, such as Helene, could improve preparedness and coordination efforts. Additionally, expanding outage reporting to cover broadband could lead to a more comprehensive understanding of service gaps during emergencies. However, lawmakers would need to weigh the benefits of subsidizing backup power for cell sites against the potential cost implications for providers and consumers. Advanced technologies like drones and satellites could also offer significant advantages in improving communication infrastructures in rural areas, but these require careful consideration and potential federal support.

Can I reproduce and distribute a CRS Report without obtaining permission?

You can reproduce and distribute a CRS Report in its entirety without permission. However, if the report includes copyrighted images or material from a third party, you need to obtain permission from the copyright holder to use those specific materials.
You are a helpful assistant that provides detailed and accurate information regarding FEMA Assistance for individuals with Limited English Proficiency.
Can you explain the challenges faced by individuals with Limited English Proficiency (LEP) during emergency situations?

Individuals with LEP encounter several challenges during emergency situations due to language barriers. These barriers can exacerbate the risks they face by making it difficult to understand evacuation notices and emergency instructions, thereby increasing the risk of casualty. Moreover, language barriers may impede access to emergency medical care and essential relief services as they might not understand the providers. Additionally, complexities arise when applying for federal aid due to difficulties in understanding applications, guidance, and instructions, potentially delaying or deterring them from seeking help, or resulting in insufficient aid awards. While FEMA provides assistance in English and Spanish and can contract for other languages, inconsistencies in translations can further hinder effective communication. Understanding these challenges is crucial for improving the delivery of assistance to individuals with LEP.
You are an expert in legal and disaster relief regulations.
Can you explain the responsibilities regarding individuals with limited English proficiency (LEP) under federal disaster relief laws?

Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 mandates that recipients of federal assistance must provide meaningful access to people with LEP. Additionally, the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act requires regulations ensuring non-discrimination in disaster relief based on English proficiency. The Post-Katrina Emergency Management Reform Act of 2006 further obliges the FEMA Administrator to collaborate with state, local, tribal, and territorial governments (SLTTs) to identify LEP populations, ensure their inclusion in disaster planning, provide access to disaster relief information, and maintain a database of successful language assistance programs for SLTT use during incidents.
You are an expert on FEMA regulations.
What do the FEMA regulations say about discrimination in disaster relief?

According to FEMA regulations, entities receiving FEMA assistance, such as SLTTs and nonprofits, are prohibited from discriminating against individuals based on national origin and other grounds when administering disaster relief. Even though LEP is not explicitly mentioned, non-discrimination is a general requirement. Noncompliance by these entities can lead to the refusal or termination of financial assistance. Additionally, it is forbidden for federal personnel or agencies to discriminate when providing federal disaster assistance.
You are familiar with the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) guidance.
What is the 2011 DHS Notice about?

The 2011 DHS Notice provides guidance to agency components, including FEMA, on the responsibilities of federal assistance recipients to ensure access to services for individuals with limited English proficiency (LEP). This guidance is designed to help these entities fulfill their obligations to offer meaningful access to their programs and services for LEP individuals.
You are an expert in federal regulations and emergency alert systems.
Can you explain the responsibilities outlined in the 2011 DHS Notice (76 Federal Register 21755) regarding access to individuals with limited English proficiency (LEP)?

The 2011 DHS Notice details the responsibilities of federal assistance recipients to ensure access for individuals with LEP. It also explains how the Department of Homeland Security evaluates compliance with these responsibilities to ensure effective communication.
You are knowledgeable about emergency alert systems in the U.S.
How are state and local agencies in the United States able to disseminate emergency alerts?

State and local agencies can send emergency alerts through FEMA’s Integrated Public Alert and Warning System (IPAWS). IPAWS distributes alerts via various channels, including radio, television, and cell phones. FEMA coordinates with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), which regulates commercial broadcast and mobile service providers participating in emergency alerting.
You specialize in FCC regulations.
What are the FCC's rules regarding the Emergency Alert System (EAS) and Wireless Emergency Alerts (WEA)?

The FCC has adopted rules for the EAS, which delivers alerts via television and radio, and for the WEA system, which mobile service providers use to send alerts to cell phones. Specifically, the FCC mandates that EAS broadcasters providing foreign language programming must transmit EAS announcements in the primary language of the EAS participant. Additionally, FCC rules require EAS participants to report actions taken to reach non-English-speaking audiences. The FCC also adopted WEA rules requiring wireless service providers to transmit WEA alerts in Spanish or containing Spanish-language characters if users specify Spanish as their preferred language.
You are informed about efforts to improve multilingual emergency alert systems.
Have there been any recent efforts to expand the number of languages available in Wireless Emergency Alerts (WEA)?

Yes, local government officials and LEP stakeholders have consistently urged the FCC to improve multilingual EAS and WEA alerting. In February 2023, 45 Members from both chambers of Congress signed a letter urging the FCC to expand the number of WEA languages. As a result, in April 2023, the FCC adopted a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking that would require providers sending WEA alerts to offer them in more languages beyond English and Spanish.

content: You are a knowledgeable assistant.
Can you tell me about the recent FCC Notice of Proposed Rulemaking related to WEA languages?

In April 2023, the FCC adopted a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking that aims to expand the languages used for Wireless Emergency Alerts (WEA). This would require providers to ensure that mobile devices can translate alerts into the 13 most commonly spoken languages in the United States. Additionally, it includes support for American Sign Language and speech-to-text capabilities. These rules are currently pending.
What is Executive Order 13166 about?

Executive Order 13166, signed by President Clinton on August 11, 2000, is focused on improving access to services for individuals with Limited English Proficiency (LEP). It requires federal agencies to develop systems that provide individuals with LEP meaningful access to their services, building on the anti-discrimination framework of Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The order mandates that agencies prepare a Language Access Plan and instructs the Department of Justice to oversee compliance and consistency across agencies.
What are the four factors used in the DOJ's analysis for ensuring 'meaningful access' to programs?

The Department of Justice uses a four-factor analysis to assess 'meaningful access' to programs and activities for individuals with Limited English Proficiency (LEP). These factors are:
1. The number or proportion of individuals with LEP served or encountered in the service population.
2. The frequency of contact with individuals with LEP.
3. The nature and importance of the program.
4. The agency’s available resources.

messages.content: You are a helpful assistant.
Can you summarize FEMA's approaches and challenges regarding language assistance for LEP individuals?

In 2016, FEMA issued a Language Access Plan (LAP), updated in 2023, to comply with Executive Order 13166. This plan outlines how FEMA assesses the needs of individuals with Limited English Proficiency (LEP) during disaster situations, providing information and interpreter services in up to 69 languages. Despite these efforts, challenges remain in trust-building with LEP individuals due to language barriers and concerns over immigration surveillance. Additionally, FEMA has experienced gaps in their bilingual workforce, as demonstrated during Hurricane María when there was a lack of Spanish-speaking staff in Puerto Rico. There is a noted need for increased appropriations to support hiring more bilingual staff and improving translation accuracy.
You are a helpful assistant.

Recent Policy Recommendations highlight the importance of hiring bilingual staff and translators for improved service delivery. In its 2022 report, the Advisory Commission on Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Pacific Islanders recommended the Office of Personnel Management guide federal agencies on this. Further suggestions include FEMA requiring grantees to identify Limited English Proficiency (LEP) communities to ensure easier access to federal relief. Incorporating LEP communities in planning and conducting direct outreach through door-to-door campaigns are also advised approaches to enhance communication with affected populations.
You are an emergency management and disaster recovery expert.
Can you tell me how FEMA supports individuals with limited English proficiency (LEP) during emergencies?

FEMA supports individuals with limited English proficiency (LEP) by engaging in targeted outreach efforts during emergencies. For instance, during the COVID-19 pandemic and Hurricane Ian, FEMA supported outreach that involved multilingual alerting options. These options are often part of commercial off-the-shelf alerting systems. However, these systems usually require individuals to subscribe or opt-in, which means that alerts may not reach those who have not subscribed, including anyone passing through the affected area.
You are a data analyst specializing in government programs.
What recommendations did FEMA's National Advisory Council make regarding language outreach?

FEMA's National Advisory Council recommended that FEMA should track the languages used to reach survivors. This initiative is part of an effort to assess the equitability of various agency programs. By tracking language outreach, FEMA can ensure that their services are reaching all communities effectively, particularly those with special language needs.

content: You are a helpful assistant.
What is ENISA?

ENISA, or the European Union Agency for Cybersecurity, is an agency dedicated to achieving a high common level of cybersecurity across Europe. It was established in 2004 and is further supported by the EU Cybersecurity Act. ENISA contributes to EU cyber policy, enhances the trustworthiness of ICT products, services, and processes through cybersecurity certification schemes, and cooperates with Member States and EU bodies. ENISA also focuses on knowledge sharing, capacity building, and awareness raising to strengthen trust in the connected economy and boost the EU’s infrastructure resilience.
Where can I find more information about ENISA?
You can find more information about ENISA and its work on their official website at www.enisa.europa.eu.
How can I contact ENISA for inquiries?
For general inquiries, you can contact the authors at cyclone@enisa.europa.eu. For media enquiries, please use press@enisa.europa.eu.
You are a helpful assistant.
Can you tell me about ENISA's copyright notice for their publications?

Certainly! ENISA, the European Union Agency for Cybersecurity, retains intellectual property rights over their publications. They permit the reuse of their documents under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) licence, as long as appropriate credit is provided and any changes made are indicated. For materials not under ENISA's copyright, permission must be obtained from the respective copyright holders.

messages.content: You are a helpful assistant for cyber crisis management.
Can you provide an overview of the complexities in managing cyber crises at the EU level?

Certainly! Cyber crisis management in the EU presents several complexities. A key challenge is the subjectivity involved in defining what constitutes a cyber crisis. Elevating a cyber incident to the level of a crisis generally requires a political decision and is influenced by the 'risk appetite' of EU Member States (MS), indicating how much risk they are willing to tolerate. Variations in interpretation among MS create difficulties at the EU level. The definition of a cyber crisis is crucial as it affects the entire management approach, from assessing its severity to choosing suitable measures for its management. Effective crisis management involves various stakeholders working at organizational, sectoral, regional, national, and EU levels, operating at strategic, operational, and technical levels. The operational level is vital as it links the strategic and technical levels by ensuring information flows across all levels.

content: You are an expert on EU cyber crisis management frameworks.
Can you explain the role of different levels in cyber crisis management in the EU?

In the EU, cyber crisis management operates on strategic, operational, and technical levels. The operational level plays a key role in bridging the gap between strategic and technical aspects. It ensures information is shared across all levels and enhances cooperation and coordination between relevant stakeholders. Cyber crisis management frameworks are integrated into general crisis management frameworks, leading to a complex ecosystem of cybersecurity actors, structures, and mechanisms. This complexity is due to the transboundary nature of cyber crises.
What are some frameworks and directives the EU has for managing cyber crises?

The EU has developed several frameworks dedicated to managing cyber crises, including the Blueprint for a coordinated response to large-scale cross-border cybersecurity incidents (2017), the Cybersecurity Act (2019), and the NIS (Network and Information Security) directive (2016). Among these, the NIS2 directive has the most significant impact on cyber crisis management across strategic, operational, and technical levels. It strengthens support for Member States, introduces new obligations, and emphasizes the EU-Cyber Crises Liaison Organisation Network (EU-CyCLONe) as a key player in cyber crisis management.
How does NIS2 improve coordination and cooperation in cyber crisis management?

NIS2 facilitates a more coordinated approach to cyber crisis management by enhancing cooperation between Member States and relevant EU institutions, bodies, and agencies. It consolidates the support of ENISA (European Union Agency for Cybersecurity) at the operational level and establishes new obligations for Member States. This ensures a more unified and effective response to cyber crises within the EU.
What is the Commission Recommendation (EU) 2017/1584 about?

The Commission Recommendation (EU) 2017/1584, issued on 13 September 2017, concerns a coordinated response to large-scale cybersecurity incidents and crises. It aims to enhance cooperation among EU member states to tackle cybersecurity threats effectively.
Can you explain the Regulation (EU) 2019/881 and its importance?

Regulation (EU) 2019/881, also known as the Cybersecurity Act, was adopted on 17 April 2019. It is key legislation that strengthens the mandate of ENISA (the European Union Agency for Cybersecurity) and establishes a framework for the cybersecurity certification of information and communications technology products. The regulation aims to enhance the overall level of cybersecurity in the EU.
What does Directive (EU) 2016/1148 entail?

Directive (EU) 2016/1148, adopted on 6 July 2016, establishes measures for achieving a high common level of security of network and information systems across the EU. It requires member states to adopt national cybersecurity strategies and impose obligations on operators of essential services and digital service providers to ensure the security of their network and information systems.
What is the purpose of the Directive (EU) 2022/2555?

The Directive (EU) 2022/2555, known as the NIS 2 Directive, aims to further enhance cybersecurity measures across the EU. It was adopted on 14 December 2022 and amends previous regulations. The directive seeks to improve the resilience and preparedness of both public and private sectors against cybersecurity threats, building upon the foundations laid by Directive (EU) 2016/1148, which it repeals.
What role does ENISA play in cyber crisis management?

ENISA plays a crucial role in cyber crisis management within the EU at the operational level. It serves as a hub for expertise and support during large-scale cybersecurity incidents, coordinating member states' response efforts. ENISA provides strategic guidance, shares best practices, and facilitates collaboration to enhance the EU's overall cyber resilience.

messages.content: You are a helpful assistant that provides information on cyber crisis management.
What are the best practices for cyber crisis management?

The best practices for cyber crisis management are categorized into different phases: prevention and preparedness.

Preparedness Phase:
- Definition of a governance structure and appointment of a crisis coordinator with operational cyber skills.
- Gathering information on critical entities and assets for rapid response.
- Establishing secured communication channels during a crisis.
- Clear allocation of roles in responding to a cyber crisis in a holistic plan.

Can you explain what distinguishes a crisis and how they are categorized?

Certainly! A crisis can be defined as a condition that significantly impacts individuals and society, threatening fundamental values and functions. It's characterized by factors such as uncertainty, risk, and severe consequences, alongside being transboundary, requiring more than ordinary resources and organization to manage. 

Crises can be categorized into three types based on their nature:

1. **Creeping Crisis**: Also known as a hidden latent crisis, it simmers under the radar and may not be detected by authorities until it suddenly erupts.
2. **Acute Crisis**: This type of crisis is sudden, unforeseen, and can cause a massive impact in a short period of time.
3. **Recurring Crisis**: Occurs regularly as part of a cycle, which means it can be anticipated to some extent.

Time sensitivity is a crucial aspect in understanding and responding to crises effectively. For example, the gradual nature of a creeping crisis might allow for preventive measures, whereas acute crises require immediate crisis mitigation strategies.

instruction: What are the key tasks involved in crisis management?
response:
Crisis management involves five key tasks that overlap and flow into each other: 

1. Sense-making: This involves discovering what is happening and understanding the reasons behind the crisis.

2. Meaning-making: This involves explaining the situation to others so they understand why it is a crisis and the necessity of certain actions.

3. Decision-making: This tasks requires taking action to resolve the situation using available resources while considering logistical, time, legal, and democratic constraints to achieve crisis resolution at all levels.

4. Termination: This task involves decision-makers determining that the crisis is over and that crisis management structures can be dissolved, although the situation might not be back to normal.

5. Learning and reform: This involves investigating and potentially changing policies and practices to improve the system based on revelations from the crisis.

These tasks help authorities tackle crucial questions and guide the organization of crisis management operations, particularly useful for cyber crisis management as per ENISA's 2014 report.

2. **Preparedness**: It aims to enhance crisis management by developing plans, establishing a resilient organizational structure, maintaining ecosystem confidence, and prioritizing critical activities. Responders are trained and prepared in advance for crisis scenarios.

3. **Response**: This phase is about dealing with the immediate crisis, preventing further damage, and deploying effective technical, operational, and strategic cooperation. It includes activating pre-determined response measures during the crisis.

Challenges during these phases include tasks like sense-making, meaning-making, decision-making, termination, and learning. Addressing these challenges is crucial for developing and improving best practices in cyber crisis management. Each phase relies on continuous learning and adaptation to evolving threats and scenarios.

content: You are an expert in cyber crisis management and NIS2 objectives. You provide detailed information and insights about best practices in cyber crisis management, specifically focusing on prevention and preparedness phases.

Each phase serves a specific purpose in managing cyber crises, with prevention and preparedness being key in reducing the likelihood of crises and ensuring readiness. The other phases, response and recovery, are essential for managing ongoing incidents and restoring systems and operations post-crisis.

Preventive measures can be implemented both before a crisis occurs and after, based on lessons learned from past events. Effective prevention strategies integrate threat analysis, situation assessments, and mitigation measures to help avoid the occurrence of crises.
How does the operational level contribute to cyber crisis management?

The operational level of cyber crisis management plays a pivotal role, particularly in the prevention and preparedness phases. It is heavily involved in threat analysis, conducting thorough situation assessments, and implementing mitigation measures. title: Promotion of Active Cyber Protection

content: In several Member States, national actors have come together to launch nationwide threat and incident mitigation programmes. The 16 members of this national consortium are Dutch organisations from different sectors, including essential and important ones such as government agencies, law enforcement, ISPs, and banks. Can you explain the categories included in the NIS cybersecurity incident taxonomy?

The cybersecurity incident taxonomy includes several categories: 

- Nature: The underlying cause that triggered the incident.
- Root cause category: System failures, natural phenomena, human error, malicious actions, third-party failures.
- Severity of the threat: High, medium, low.
- Impact: The effect on services and specific sectors of the economy/society.
- Sectors impacted: Energy, transport, banking, finance, health, drinking water, digital infrastructure, communications, trust and identification services, digital services, government services.
- Scale of the national impact on the economy and society: Red – very large impact, yellow – marginal impact, green – minor impact, white – no impact.
- Outlook: The prognosis for the impact on the economy and society: improving, stable, worsening.

It builds upon the original NIS Directive, strengthening requirements on member states to protect Essential and Important Entities. One of the key components of NIS2 is the mandate for each member state to develop a national large-scale cybersecurity incident and crisis response plan. This plan must outline the objectives, management arrangements, tasks, and responsibilities for handling significant cybersecurity incidents and crises. By establishing a clear and structured approach, NIS2 ensures a more coordinated and effective response to cyber threats, contributing to the resilience and security of critical infrastructures across the EU.

The response phase aims to manage a cyber crisis to prevent further damage. At the EU level, effective response requires technical, operational, and strategic cooperation among Member States. Here are some best practices for this phase:

Can you explain the process for becoming a qualified service provider according to BSI?

Qualified service providers for security incidents are private companies selected through a two-stage process. Initially, applicants must submit comprehensive documentation to BSI for assessment. This includes a description of their products and services, compliance with specified criteria, and existing certifications. Next, they must pass a technical interview at BSI, demonstrating their ability to professionally manage an incident using a fictitious scenario. Successful providers appear on BSI’s list based on performance criteria such as 24/7 availability, ISO 27001 certification, head office location, internal resources for APT incident response, additional services (like legal and crisis communication), and technical equipment capabilities.

The team should be involved at all times to help manage the crisis effectively. This does not mean that everything should be disclosed immediately. It is crucial to gain time to understand the extent of the situation better. Communications should avoid mentioning the causes of the incident, responsible persons, or possible consequences until the investigation is complete. This aligns with the good practices outlined by the Spanish National Cryptologic Centre and supports the NIS2 objective of identifying capabilities and procedures for crisis management.
What is the recovery phase in cyber crisis management?

The recovery phase in cyber crisis management aims to enable member states and the EU to recover quickly by implementing measures as soon as a crisis is over. This includes restoring and reintegrating affected systems and organizing lessons learned to better prevent, respond to, and mitigate future incidents. The goal is to return to a normal or even higher level of security than before the crisis.

What is meant by 'creeping crisis' as described by Boin, Ekengren, and Rhinard?

The concept of a 'creeping crisis' as described by Boin, Ekengren, and Rhinard refers to crises that develop slowly over time, often without immediate recognition. These crises are challenging to address because they do not manifest as sudden or catastrophic events, which can make them difficult to detect and manage effectively. The authors suggest that understanding and conceptualizing such crises is crucial for developing better strategies for crisis management and policy intervention.
How did the European Union perform in crisis management during the COVID-19 pandemic according to Boin and Rhinard?

The authors highlight issues such as coordination problems, varying national responses, and initial unpreparedness. However, they also point out that the pandemic led to improvements in some areas, including increased collaboration between member states and enhanced mechanisms for joint crisis response. The article emphasizes the need for further integration and development of EU-wide crisis management capabilities.

Through this instrument, the EU seeks to strengthen its international partnerships and reinforce its stance on cybersecurity norms and regulations.

messages.content: You are a helpful assistant.
Can you give me an overview of emergency communications issues discussed in the 116th Congress?

First responders and other emergency personnel use emergency communications systems to communicate during day-to-day operations and major disasters. These systems include: 911 systems for public assistance calls, land mobile radio systems for communication among police and EMS, the First Responder Network for nationwide safety communications, and alerting systems for public warnings. However, these systems use different technologies, leading to interoperability issues. Efforts are underway to use Internet Protocol-based technologies to improve these issues.

content: You are a helpful and informative assistant.
Tell me about how public safety agencies are improving communications.

Federal, state, and local public safety agencies are investing in Internet Protocol (IP) -based technologies to improve communications, coordination, and response. The federal government has created an IP-based national alerting system that allows authorized agencies to send a single alert through multiple alerting systems. Additionally, the government has invested in FirstNet, a nationwide seamless, IP-based, high-speed mobile communications network for public safety users. There is also interest in upgrading 911 systems to next generation, IP-based systems that enable better data sharing and systems interconnectivity.
What opportunities and challenges do new technologies bring for emergency communications?

As emergency communications systems converge toward a common IP-based platform, there are both opportunities and challenges. Advancements in geo-location technologies can help find 911 callers more easily, but integrating these into legacy systems can be challenging. New alerting technologies enable officials to send alerts to mobile phones, though some people still rely on landlines. Interconnecting systems can improve information sharing but also raise privacy and security concerns as data flows across multiple networks. These changes may require new policies and collaborative planning across all levels of government.
Are there any financial implications for transitioning to new emergency communication technologies?

Yes, migrating to new emergency communication technologies can be costly. Not all jurisdictions may be able to afford the transition, which might lead to disparities in emergency response capabilities across different areas. Financial support or funding mechanisms may be needed to ensure equitable access to advanced communication technologies for all public safety agencies.

content: You are a helpful assistant specialized in telecommunications and emergency communications policy.
What roles does Congress have in supporting emergency communications?

Congress has several roles in supporting emergency communications. It may focus on federal grant programs that fund such communications. Additionally, Congress often examines the activities of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) through its Public Safety and Homeland Security Bureau (PSHSB). The PSHSB administers policies related to emergency communications, including rules for 911 services, the use of 911 fees by state and local governments, public safety spectrum, public alerts, and disaster management and network outage reporting. Congress may also oversee restoration efforts after disasters.

Jill C. Gallagher is an Analyst in Telecommunications Policy.
What is the role of the Congressional Research Service in relation to Congress?

The Congressional Research Service (CRS) serves as nonpartisan shared staff to congressional committees and Members of Congress. It provides policy and legal analysis to committees and members, supporting the legislative process. The CRS operates solely at the behest of and under the direction of Congress, ensuring that Members have access to unbiased and factual information to inform their decision-making.
Is it possible to reproduce a CRS Report and are there any restrictions?

Yes, it is possible to reproduce and distribute a CRS Report in its entirety without permission from CRS, as they are works of the United States Government and thus not subject to copyright protection within the U.S. However, if a CRS Report includes copyrighted images or material from a third party, you may need to obtain permission from the copyright holder if you wish to copy or use that copyrighted material.
